# frozen_string_literal: true

module Ai
  class Conversation < ActiveRecord::Base
    self.table_name = 'conversations'

    include HasJsonDefaults

    # Associations
    belongs_to :ai_page, class_name: 'Ai::AiPage', optional: true
    has_many :messages, dependent: :destroy
    has_many :sessions, dependent: :destroy

    # Validations
    validates :source, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[web cli scheduled_task whatsapp] }

    # Scopes
    scope :recent, -> { order(last_message_at: :desc) }
    scope :by_source, ->(source) { where(source: source) }

    # Defaults
    json_defaults context: {}

    # Callbacks
    after_initialize :set_last_message_at, if: :new_record?

    # Methods
    def add_message(role:, content:, metadata: {})
      messages.create!(
        role: role,
        content: content,
        metadata: metadata
      ).tap do
        touch(:last_message_at)
      end
    end

    def active_session
      sessions.where(status: 'running').order(created_at: :desc).first
    end

    def latest_messages(limit = 10)
      messages.order(created_at: :desc).limit(limit).reverse
    end

    private

    def set_last_message_at
      self.last_message_at ||= Time.current
    end
  end
end

# frozen_string_literal: true

module Ai
  class AiPage < ActiveRecord::Base
    self.table_name = 'ai_pages'

    include HasStatus

    # Validations
    validates :title, presence: true
    validates :slug, presence: true, uniqueness: true
    validates :content, length: { maximum: 1_000_000 }, allow_blank: true
    validates :status, presence: true, inclusion: { in: %w[draft published archived] }

    has_many :conversations, foreign_key: :ai_page_id, dependent: :nullify
    has_many :canvas_components, dependent: :destroy

    # Statuses
    statuses :draft, :published, :archived
    scope :recent, -> { order(created_at: :desc) }

    # Callbacks
    before_validation :generate_slug, if: -> { slug.blank? }

    # Methods
    def publish!
      update!(status: 'published', published_at: Time.current)
    end

    def archive!
      update!(status: 'archived')
    end

    private

    def generate_slug
      return unless title.present?

      base_slug = title.parameterize
      self.slug = base_slug

      counter = 1
      while AiPage.exists?(slug: slug)
        self.slug = "#{base_slug}-#{counter}"
        counter += 1
      end
    end
  end
end

# frozen_string_literal: true require 'roda' require 'tilt/erubi' require 'json' require_relative 'turbo_broadcast' require_relative 'view_helpers' module Ai module Web class App < Roda plugin :render, views: File.expand_path('views', __dir__) plugin :public, root: File.expand_path('public', __dir__) plugin :json plugin :halt plugin :all_verbs plugin :symbol_views plugin :streaming # Make models and helpers available in views plugin :render_locals, locals: { Conversation: Ai::Conversation, Message: Ai::Message, SkillRecord: Ai::SkillRecord, Config: Ai::Config, Notification: Ai::Notification } include ViewHelpers def turbo_frame_request? env['HTTP_TURBO_FRAME'] == 'canvas-content' end def render_canvas_or_layout(template) if turbo_frame_request? content = render(template) "
#{content}
" else view template end end def sse_stream(channel) queue = Thread::Queue.new subscriber = TurboBroadcast.subscribe(channel) { |html| queue.push(html) } Ai.logger.info "[SSE] Connection opened for #{channel}" response['Content-Type'] = 'text/event-stream' response['Cache-Control'] = 'no-cache' response['X-Accel-Buffering'] = 'no' stream(loop: true, callback: proc { Ai.logger.info "[SSE] Connection closed for #{channel}" TurboBroadcast.unsubscribe(channel, subscriber) }) do |out| html = queue.pop(timeout: 30) if html Ai.logger.info "[SSE] Sending event to #{channel} (#{html.length} bytes)" out << "data: #{html.gsub("\n", "\ndata: ")}\n\n" else out << ": heartbeat\n\n" end end end route do |r| r.public # Root - redirect to conversations r.root do r.redirect '/conversations' end # Conversations routes r.on 'conversations' do # List all conversations r.is do r.get do @conversations = Conversation.recent.limit(50) render_canvas_or_layout(:conversations_index) end # Create new conversation r.post do content = r.params['content']&.strip conversation = Conversation.create!( title: 'New Conversation', source: 'web' ) if content && !content.empty? message = conversation.add_message(role: 'user', content: content) Ai::Jobs::AgentExecutorJob.perform_later(message.id) end r.redirect "/conversations/#{conversation.id}" end end # Individual conversation r.on Integer do |id| @conversation = Conversation.find(id) r.is do r.get do @messages = @conversation.messages.chronological render_canvas_or_layout(:conversation_show) end end # Chat panel fragment (no layout) r.on 'panel' do r.get do @messages = @conversation.messages.chronological render(:conversation_panel) end end # Canvas content r.on 'canvas' do r.get do response['Content-Type'] = 'text/html' if @conversation.ai_page @conversation.ai_page.content.presence || '
Canvas is empty
' else '
Canvas is empty
' end end end # SSE stream for Turbo Stream updates r.on 'stream' do r.get do sse_stream("conversation:#{@conversation.id}") end end # Messages for this conversation r.on 'messages' do r.post do content = r.params['content'] unless content && !content.strip.empty? r.halt 400, { error: 'Message content required' } end message = @conversation.add_message( role: 'user', content: content ) Ai::Jobs::AgentExecutorJob.perform_later(message.id) if r.params['turbo'] message_html = render_message_html(message) response['Content-Type'] = 'text/vnd.turbo-stream.html' turbo_stream('append', "messages-#{@conversation.id}") { message_html } + turbo_stream('replace', 'message-form') do <<~HTML
HTML end else # Plain POST from footer panel — just return 200 response.status = 200 { status: 'ok' } end end end end end # AI Pages (individual page by slug) r.on 'pages', String do |slug| @page = AiPage.published.find_by!(slug: slug) render_canvas_or_layout(:page_show) end # Notifications r.on 'notifications' do # SSE stream r.on 'stream' do r.get do sse_stream('notifications') end end # Mark read r.on Integer, 'read' do |id| r.post do notification = Ai::Notification.find(id) notification.mark_read! r.redirect '/notifications' end end # Start chat from notification r.on Integer, 'chat' do |id| r.post do notification = Ai::Notification.find(id) conversation = notification.start_conversation! r.redirect "/conversations/#{conversation.id}" end end # List r.is do r.get do @notifications = Ai::Notification.recent.limit(50) render_canvas_or_layout(:notifications) end end end # Jobs & Skills r.on 'jobs' do r.is do r.get do @tasks = Ai::ScheduledTask.order(scheduled_for: :desc) @skills = SkillRecord.all.order(usage_count: :desc) render_canvas_or_layout(:jobs_and_skills) end end end # Settings r.on 'settings' do r.is do r.get do @skills = SkillRecord.all.order(usage_count: :desc) @mcp_connections = McpConnection.all @config = Config.all_config render_canvas_or_layout(:settings) end end end # Webhooks r.on 'webhooks' do r.on 'whatsapp' do r.post do raw_body = r.body.read unless Ai::WhatsApp.verify_signature(raw_body, r.env['HTTP_X_WEBHOOK_SIGNATURE']) r.halt 401, { error: 'Invalid signature' } end payload = JSON.parse(raw_body) Ai::WhatsApp.handle_inbound(payload) { status: 'ok' } end end end # Health check r.on 'health' do { status: 'ok', timestamp: Time.now.iso8601 } end # API routes r.on 'api' do r.on 'conversations' do r.is do r.get do conversations = Conversation.recent.limit(20).map do |c| { id: c.id, title: c.title, source: c.source, message_count: c.messages.count, last_message_at: c.last_message_at } end { conversations: conversations } end r.post do ai_page_id = r.params['ai_page_id'] conversation = Conversation.create!( title: 'New Conversation', source: 'web', ai_page_id: ai_page_id ) { id: conversation.id, title: conversation.title, ai_page_id: conversation.ai_page_id } end end end # Create canvas (AiPage + Conversation together) r.on 'canvases' do r.post do page = AiPage.create!( title: r.params['title'] || 'New Canvas', content: '', status: 'published', published_at: Time.current ) conversation = Conversation.create!( title: page.title, source: 'web', ai_page: page ) { id: conversation.id, title: conversation.title, ai_page_id: page.id, page_slug: page.slug } end end # Page canvas content by page ID r.on 'pages', Integer do |page_id| page = AiPage.find(page_id) r.on 'canvas' do r.get do { components: page.canvas_components.ordered.map(&:as_canvas_json), canvas_state: page.canvas_state || {} } end end r.on 'components' do r.is do r.post do body = JSON.parse(r.body.read) rescue r.params component = page.canvas_components.create!( component_type: body['component_type'] || 'card', content: body['content'] || '', x: body['x']&.to_f || 0, y: body['y']&.to_f || 0, width: body['width']&.to_f || 320, height: body['height']&.to_f, z_index: body['z_index']&.to_i || 0, metadata: body['metadata'] || {} ) # Broadcast Turbo Stream append style = "left:#{component.x}px;top:#{component.y}px;width:#{component.width}px;" style += "height:#{component.height}px;" if component.height html = <<~HTML
#{component.content}
HTML turbo = "" page.conversations.each do |conv| TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conv.id}", turbo) end component.as_canvas_json end end r.on Integer do |component_id| component = page.canvas_components.find(component_id) r.get do component.as_canvas_json end r.patch do updates = {} %w[x y width height z_index].each do |attr| updates[attr] = r.params[attr].to_f if r.params[attr] end component.update!(updates) if updates.any? component.as_canvas_json end r.delete do turbo = "" page.conversations.each do |conv| TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conv.id}", turbo) end component.destroy! { success: true } end end end end end end end end end

# frozen_string_literal: true require 'redcarpet' module Ai module Tools class SendMessageTool < FastMcp::Tool tool_name 'send_message' description 'Send a message back to the user' arguments do required(:content).filled(:string).description('Message content to send') optional(:conversation_id).filled(:integer).description('Conversation ID (defaults to current)') end def call(content:, conversation_id: nil) conversation = if conversation_id Conversation.find(conversation_id) elsif ENV['CONVERSATION_ID'] Conversation.find(ENV['CONVERSATION_ID']) else Conversation.last end unless conversation return { success: false, error: 'No conversation found' } end message = conversation.add_message(role: 'assistant', content: content) # Broadcast via TurboBroadcast so the message appears in the UI in real-time broadcast_message(conversation, message) Ai.logger.info "Message sent to conversation #{conversation.id}" { success: true, message_id: message.id, conversation_id: conversation.id } rescue => e Ai.logger.error "Failed to send message: #{e.message}" { success: false, error: e.message } end private def broadcast_message(conversation, message) renderer = Redcarpet::Markdown.new( Redcarpet::Render::HTML.new(hard_wrap: true, link_attributes: { target: '_blank', rel: 'noopener' }), fenced_code_blocks: true, tables: true, autolink: true, strikethrough: true, no_intra_emphasis: true ) time = message.created_at.strftime('%I:%M %p') content_html = renderer.render(message.content) message_html = <<~HTML
AI #{time}
#{content_html}
HTML turbo_html = "" \ "" Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conversation.id}", turbo_html) rescue => e Ai.logger.error "Failed to broadcast message: #{e.message}" end end end end

# frozen_string_literal: true

module Ai
  module Tools
    class RemoveCanvasComponentTool < FastMcp::Tool
      tool_name 'remove_canvas_component'
      description 'Remove a component from the canvas'

      arguments do
        required(:component_id).filled(:integer).description('ID of the component to remove')
      end

      def call(component_id:)
        component = CanvasComponent.find_by(id: component_id)
        return { success: false, error: "Component #{component_id} not found" } unless component

        page = component.ai_page
        component.destroy!

        turbo = "<turbo-stream action=\"remove\" target=\"canvas-component-#{component_id}\"><template></template></turbo-stream>"
        page.conversations.each do |conv|
          Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conv.id}", turbo)
        end

        {
          success: true,
          removed_id: component_id
        }
      rescue => e
        Ai.logger.error "Failed to remove canvas component: #{e.message}"
        { success: false, error: e.message }
      end
    end
  end
end

    class RemoveCanvasComponentTool < FastMcp::Tool
      tool_name 'remove_canvas_component'
      description 'Remove a component from the canvas'

      arguments do

        }
      rescue => e
        Ai.logger.error "Failed to remove canvas component: #{e.message}"

      end
    end

# frozen_string_literal: true require 'roda' require 'tilt/erubi' require 'json' require_relative 'turbo_broadcast' require_relative 'view_helpers' module Ai module Web class App < Roda plugin :render, views: File.expand_path('views', __dir__) plugin :public, root: File.expand_path('public', __dir__) plugin :json plugin :halt plugin :all_verbs plugin :symbol_views plugin :streaming # Make models and helpers available in views plugin :render_locals, locals: { Conversation: Ai::Conversation, Message: Ai::Message, SkillRecord: Ai::SkillRecord, Config: Ai::Config, Notification: Ai::Notification } include ViewHelpers def turbo_frame_request? env['HTTP_TURBO_FRAME'] == 'canvas-content' end def render_canvas_or_layout(template) if turbo_frame_request? content = render(template) "
#{content}
" else view template end end def sse_stream(channel) queue = Thread::Queue.new subscriber = TurboBroadcast.subscribe(channel) { |html| queue.push(html) } Ai.logger.info "[SSE] Connection opened for #{channel}" response['Content-Type'] = 'text/event-stream' response['Cache-Control'] = 'no-cache' response['X-Accel-Buffering'] = 'no' stream(loop: true, callback: proc { Ai.logger.info "[SSE] Connection closed for #{channel}" TurboBroadcast.unsubscribe(channel, subscriber) }) do |out| html = queue.pop(timeout: 30) if html Ai.logger.info "[SSE] Sending event to #{channel} (#{html.length} bytes)" out << "data: #{html.gsub("\n", "\ndata: ")}\n\n" else out << ": heartbeat\n\n" end end end route do |r| r.public # Root - redirect to conversations r.root do r.redirect '/conversations' end # Conversations routes r.on 'conversations' do # List all conversations r.is do r.get do @conversations = Conversation.recent.limit(50) render_canvas_or_layout(:conversations_index) end # Create new conversation r.post do content = r.params['content']&.strip conversation = Conversation.create!( title: 'New Conversation', source: 'web' ) if content && !content.empty? message = conversation.add_message(role: 'user', content: content) Ai::Jobs::AgentExecutorJob.perform_later(message.id) end r.redirect "/conversations/#{conversation.id}" end end # Individual conversation r.on Integer do |id| @conversation = Conversation.find(id) r.is do r.get do @messages = @conversation.messages.chronological render_canvas_or_layout(:conversation_show) end end # Chat panel fragment (no layout) r.on 'panel' do r.get do @messages = @conversation.messages.chronological render(:conversation_panel) end end # Canvas content r.on 'canvas' do r.get do response['Content-Type'] = 'text/html' if @conversation.ai_page @conversation.ai_page.content.presence || '
Canvas is empty
' else '
Canvas is empty
' end end end # SSE stream for Turbo Stream updates r.on 'stream' do r.get do sse_stream("conversation:#{@conversation.id}") end end # Messages for this conversation r.on 'messages' do r.post do content = r.params['content'] unless content && !content.strip.empty? r.halt 400, { error: 'Message content required' } end message = @conversation.add_message( role: 'user', content: content ) Ai::Jobs::AgentExecutorJob.perform_later(message.id) if r.params['turbo'] message_html = render_message_html(message) response['Content-Type'] = 'text/vnd.turbo-stream.html' turbo_stream('append', "messages-#{@conversation.id}") { message_html } + turbo_stream('replace', 'message-form') do <<~HTML
HTML end else # Plain POST from footer panel — just return 200 response.status = 200 { status: 'ok' } end end end end end # AI Pages (individual page by slug) r.on 'pages', String do |slug| @page = AiPage.published.find_by!(slug: slug) render_canvas_or_layout(:page_show) end # Notifications r.on 'notifications' do # SSE stream r.on 'stream' do r.get do sse_stream('notifications') end end # Mark read r.on Integer, 'read' do |id| r.post do notification = Ai::Notification.find(id) notification.mark_read! r.redirect '/notifications' end end # Start chat from notification r.on Integer, 'chat' do |id| r.post do notification = Ai::Notification.find(id) conversation = notification.start_conversation! r.redirect "/conversations/#{conversation.id}" end end # List r.is do r.get do @notifications = Ai::Notification.recent.limit(50) render_canvas_or_layout(:notifications) end end end # Jobs & Skills r.on 'jobs' do r.is do r.get do @tasks = Ai::ScheduledTask.order(scheduled_for: :desc) @skills = SkillRecord.all.order(usage_count: :desc) render_canvas_or_layout(:jobs_and_skills) end end end # Settings r.on 'settings' do r.is do r.get do @skills = SkillRecord.all.order(usage_count: :desc) @mcp_connections = McpConnection.all @config = Config.all_config render_canvas_or_layout(:settings) end end end # Webhooks r.on 'webhooks' do r.on 'whatsapp' do r.post do raw_body = r.body.read unless Ai::WhatsApp.verify_signature(raw_body, r.env['HTTP_X_WEBHOOK_SIGNATURE']) r.halt 401, { error: 'Invalid signature' } end payload = JSON.parse(raw_body) Ai::WhatsApp.handle_inbound(payload) { status: 'ok' } end end end # Health check r.on 'health' do { status: 'ok', timestamp: Time.now.iso8601 } end # API routes r.on 'api' do r.on 'conversations' do r.is do r.get do conversations = Conversation.recent.limit(20).map do |c| { id: c.id, title: c.title, source: c.source, message_count: c.messages.count, last_message_at: c.last_message_at } end { conversations: conversations } end r.post do ai_page_id = r.params['ai_page_id'] conversation = Conversation.create!( title: 'New Conversation', source: 'web', ai_page_id: ai_page_id ) { id: conversation.id, title: conversation.title, ai_page_id: conversation.ai_page_id } end end end # Create canvas (AiPage + Conversation together) r.on 'canvases' do r.post do page = AiPage.create!( title: r.params['title'] || 'New Canvas', content: '', status: 'published', published_at: Time.current ) conversation = Conversation.create!( title: page.title, source: 'web', ai_page: page ) { id: conversation.id, title: conversation.title, ai_page_id: page.id, page_slug: page.slug } end end # Page canvas content by page ID r.on 'pages', Integer do |page_id| page = AiPage.find(page_id) r.on 'canvas' do r.get do { components: page.canvas_components.ordered.map(&:as_canvas_json), canvas_state: page.canvas_state || {} } end end r.on 'components' do r.is do r.post do body = JSON.parse(r.body.read) rescue r.params component = page.canvas_components.create!( component_type: body['component_type'] || 'card', content: body['content'] || '', x: body['x']&.to_f || 0, y: body['y']&.to_f || 0, width: body['width']&.to_f || 320, height: body['height']&.to_f, z_index: body['z_index']&.to_i || 0, metadata: body['metadata'] || {} ) # Broadcast Turbo Stream append style = "left:#{component.x}px;top:#{component.y}px;width:#{component.width}px;" style += "height:#{component.height}px;" if component.height html = <<~HTML
#{component.content}
HTML turbo = "" page.conversations.each do |conv| TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conv.id}", turbo) end component.as_canvas_json end end r.on Integer do |component_id| component = page.canvas_components.find(component_id) r.get do component.as_canvas_json end r.patch do updates = {} %w[x y width height z_index].each do |attr| updates[attr] = r.params[attr].to_f if r.params[attr] end component.update!(updates) if updates.any? component.as_canvas_json end r.delete do turbo = "" page.conversations.each do |conv| TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conv.id}", turbo) end component.destroy! { success: true } end end end end end end end end end

# frozen_string_literal: true

module Ai
  module Tools
    class UpdateCanvasTool < FastMcp::Tool
      tool_name 'update_canvas'
      description 'Update the canvas area for the current conversation with HTML content. The canvas is a large display area above the chat that can show rich content like dashboards, reports, or interactive pages. Creates a named AiPage if none exists.'

      arguments do
        required(:html).filled(:string).description('HTML content to display in the canvas')
        optional(:title).filled(:string).description('Canvas page title (used when creating a new canvas page)')
        optional(:conversation_id).filled(:integer).description('Conversation ID (defaults to current)')
        optional(:mode).filled(:string).description('How to update: "replace" (default) replaces all content, "append" adds to existing content')
      end

      def call(html:, title: nil, conversation_id: nil, mode: 'replace')
        conversation = if conversation_id
          Ai::Conversation.find(conversation_id)
        elsif ENV['CONVERSATION_ID']
          Ai::Conversation.find(ENV['CONVERSATION_ID'])
        else
          Ai::Conversation.last
        end

        unless conversation
          return { success: false, error: 'No conversation found' }
        end

        # Auto-create an AiPage if conversation has none
        page = conversation.ai_page
        unless page
          page_title = title || conversation.title || 'Canvas'
          page = Ai::AiPage.create!(
            title: page_title,
            content: '',
            status: 'published',
            published_at: Time.current
          )
          conversation.update!(ai_page: page)
        end

        # Update page content
        if mode == 'append'
          page.update!(content: (page.content || '') + html)
        else
          page.update!(content: html)
        end

        # Broadcast to ALL conversations sharing this page
        action = mode == 'append' ? 'append' : 'update'
        target = "canvas-page-#{page.id}"
        stream_html = "<turbo-stream action=\"#{action}\" target=\"#{target}\"><template>#{html}</template></turbo-stream>"

        page.conversations.each do |conv|
          Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conv.id}", stream_html)
        end

        { success: true, mode: mode, conversation_id: conversation.id, ai_page_id: page.id, slug: page.slug }
      rescue => e
        { success: false, error: e.message }
      end
    end
  end
end

      def call(html:, title: nil, conversation_id: nil, mode: 'replace')
        conversation = if conversation_id
          Ai::Conversation.find(conversation_id)
        elsif ENV['CONVERSATION_ID']
          Ai::Conversation.find(ENV['CONVERSATION_ID'])
        else
          Ai::Conversation.last
        end

        unless conversation
          return { success: false, error: 'No conversation found' }
        end

        # Auto-create an AiPage if conversation has none
        page = conversation.ai_page
        unless page
          page_title = title || conversation.title || 'Canvas'
          page = Ai::AiPage.create!(
            title: page_title,
            content: '',
            status: 'published',
            published_at: Time.current
          )
          conversation.update!(ai_page: page)
        end

        # Update page content
        if mode == 'append'
          page.update!(content: (page.content || '') + html)
        else
          page.update!(content: html)
        end

        # Broadcast to ALL conversations sharing this page
        action = mode == 'append' ? 'append' : 'update'
        target = "canvas-page-#{page.id}"
        stream_html = "<turbo-stream action=\"#{action}\" target=\"#{target}\"><template>#{html}</template></turbo-stream>"

        page.conversations.each do |conv|
          Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("conversation:#{conv.id}", stream_html)
        end

        { success: true, mode: mode, conversation_id: conversation.id, ai_page_id: page.id, slug: page.slug }
      rescue => e
        { success: false, error: e.message }
      end
    end
  end
end

        height: height,
        z_index: z_index,
        metadata: metadata || {}
      }
    end
  end

Done. Here's what "Chat about this" now does:

1. **Creates a new conversation** in the same canvas via `POST /api/conversations` with `ai_page_id` and a `title` derived from the widget's content (first line, up to 50 chars, or "Widget #ID" as fallback)

3. **Prefills the textarea** with `[Re: canvas widget #ID]` and a preview of the widget content, so the user can add their question before sending
4. The component gets the highlight pulse animation as before

The API endpoint was also updated to accept an optional `title` parameter when creating conversations.

# Canvas-First Architecture Refactor ## Context The app has a thread exhaustion problem: each conversation tab opens its own SSE connection, and Puma threads are finite. The root cause is that conversations — not canvases — are the primary unit. This refactor makes **canvases the primary unit**, consolidates SSE to one connection per canvas, removes the `/conversations` index page, introduces a two-level tab bar, and adds URL-driven routing so every canvas and chat has a shareable URL. ## URL Scheme ``` / → home (redirect to last canvas or empty state) /:canvas_slug → opens canvas, switches to its last active chat /:canvas_slug/:chat_slug → opens canvas + specific chat tab /notifications → notifications (turbo-frame, no canvas) /jobs → jobs & skills (turbo-frame) /settings → settings (turbo-frame) ``` Browser URL updates via `history.pushState` as tabs switch — no full page reloads. ## Files to Modify | File | What changes | |---|---| | `ai/models/conversation.rb` | Add `slug` generation, `ensure_canvas!`, `broadcast_channel` | | `ai/models/ai_page.rb` | No changes (already has slug) | | `workspace/migrations/new` | Add `slug` column to conversations | | `web/app.rb` | New canvas SSE route, URL-based routing for `/:slug/:chat_slug`, remove `/conversations` index, update broadcasts | | `ai/jobs/agent_executor_job.rb` | Broadcast to `conversation.broadcast_channel` | | `ai/tools/send_message_tool.rb` | Same | | `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Single `broadcast("canvas:#{page.id}")` | | `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Same | | `ai/tools/remove_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Same | | `web/public/js/controllers/chat_footer_controller.js` | Two-level tabs, one SSE per canvas, pushState URL sync | | `web/views/layout.erb` | Two-row tab bar HTML, update sidebar links | | `web/public/css/style.css` | Two-level tab bar styling | **Delete:** `web/views/conversations_index.erb` **Create:** `web/views/home.erb`, migration file ## Implementation ### Step 1: Migration — Add slug to conversations Create `workspace/migrations/YYYYMMDDNNNNNN_add_slug_to_conversations.rb`: ```ruby class AddSlugToConversations < ActiveRecord::Migration[8.0] def change add_column :conversations, :slug, :string add_index :conversations, :slug, unique: true end end ``` ### Step 2: Conversation model updates In `ai/models/conversation.rb`: ```ruby # Slug generation (same pattern as AiPage) before_validation :generate_slug, if: -> { slug.blank? } def ensure_canvas! return ai_page if ai_page page = Ai::AiPage.create!(title: title.presence || 'Untitled Canvas', content: '', status: 'draft') update!(ai_page_id: page.id) reload.ai_page end def broadcast_channel "canvas:#{ensure_canvas!.id}" end private def generate_slug base = (title.presence || "chat-#{SecureRandom.hex(3)}").parameterize self.slug = base counter = 1 while Conversation.exists?(slug: slug) self.slug = "#{base}-#{counter}" counter += 1 end end ``` Backfill existing conversations: run a one-off in the migration or seed. ### Step 3: Canvas SSE route In `web/app.rb`, inside `r.on 'api'` > `r.on 'pages', Integer do |page_id|`, add: ```ruby r.on 'stream' do r.get do sse_stream("canvas:#{page.id}") end end ``` ### Step 4: Migrate all 7 broadcast sites to canvas channel **`agent_executor_job.rb`** lines 65, 83 — change `"conversation:#{conversation.id}"` to `conversation.broadcast_channel` **`send_message_tool.rb`** line 71 — same **`add_canvas_component_tool.rb`** `broadcast_to_page` — replace `page.conversations.each` loop with single `Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:#{page.id}", turbo)` **`update_canvas_component_tool.rb`** lines 51-53 — same simplification **`remove_canvas_component_tool.rb`** lines 21-23 — same **`web/app.rb`** POST/DELETE component routes — same (replace `page.conversations.each` with single broadcast) ### Step 5: URL routing in `web/app.rb` Remove the conversations index route. Change root: ```ruby r.root do recent = AiPage.published.recent.first if recent r.redirect "/#{recent.slug}" else render_canvas_or_layout(:home) end end ``` Add catch-all canvas/chat routes **after** all other named routes (`notifications`, `jobs`, `settings`, `api`, `webhooks`, `health`): ```ruby # Canvas URL: /:canvas_slug or /:canvas_slug/:chat_slug r.on String do |canvas_slug| @page = AiPage.find_by(slug: canvas_slug) next unless @page # fall through to 404 r.on String do |chat_slug| @conversation = @page.conversations.find_by(slug: chat_slug) # Return page data — JS handles the tab activation render_canvas_or_layout(:canvas_view) end r.is do render_canvas_or_layout(:canvas_view) end end ``` Create `web/views/canvas_view.erb` — minimal template that passes page/conversation data to JS: ```erb ``` Create `web/views/home.erb`: ```erb

Open a canvas from the sidebar, or create one with + below.

``` Delete `web/views/conversations_index.erb`. ### Step 6: Two-level tab bar — Layout HTML In `web/views/layout.erb`, replace the tab bar section inside `.chat-footer`: ```html
``` Update sidebar: `openCanvasTab(...)` → `openCanvas(...)`. ### Step 7: CSS — Two-level tab bar ```css .chat-tab-bar.canvas-level { background: var(--muted); border-bottom: none; } .chat-tab-bar.conversation-level { min-height: 1.75rem; padding-left: 0.5rem; } .chat-tab-bar.conversation-level .chat-tab { font-size: 0.6875rem; height: 1.75rem; } ``` ### Step 8: Chat footer controller rewrite **New state:** ```js this.canvases = [] // [{ pageId, title, slug, conversations: [{ id, title, slug }], activeConvId }] this.activeCanvasPageId = null this.eventSources = {} // pageId → EventSource (ONE per canvas) ``` **New targets:** `canvasTabs`, `conversationTabs`, `conversationTabBar`, `panels` **Key methods:** | Method | Purpose | |---|---| | `newTab()` | POST `/api/canvases` → `openCanvas()` | | `openCanvas(pageId, title, slug, convId?, convTitle?, convSlug?)` | Open/switch canvas tab, connect SSE to `/api/pages/${pageId}/stream`, create canvas overlay. If convId provided, open that conversation. Otherwise create one. | | `newConversation()` | POST `/api/conversations` with active canvas pageId → `openConversation()` | | `openConversation(convId, title, slug, pageId)` | Add conversation tab in bottom row, create panel, load via `GET /conversations/${convId}/panel` | | `switchCanvas(pageId)` | Toggle canvas tabs/overlays, re-render conversation tabs, pushState URL | | `switchConversation(convId)` | Toggle conversation tabs/panels, pushState URL | | `closeCanvas(pageId)` | Close SSE, remove panels + overlay | | `closeConversation(convId)` | Remove panel, if last → close canvas | | `connectSSE(pageId)` | One EventSource to `/api/pages/${pageId}/stream` | **URL sync:** ```js updateURL() { const canvas = this.canvases.find(c => c.pageId === this.activeCanvasPageId) if (!canvas) return history.pushState(null, '', '/') const conv = canvas.conversations.find(c => c.id === canvas.activeConvId) const path = conv ? `/${canvas.slug}/${conv.slug}` : `/${canvas.slug}` if (location.pathname !== path) history.pushState(null, '', path) } ``` Called at the end of `switchCanvas()` and `switchConversation()`. **`popstate` handler** — on browser back/forward, parse URL and switch to matching canvas/conversation. **Persistence:** sessionStorage key `chatState`: ```js { canvases: [...], activeCanvasPageId } ``` On `connect()`, handle old `chatOpenTabs` format gracefully (discard it). **API response changes:** `POST /api/canvases` and `POST /api/conversations` must return slug in response JSON. ### Step 9: Update API responses In `web/app.rb`: `POST /api/canvases` — add `page_slug` (already returned) and `conv_slug`: ```ruby { id: conversation.id, title: conversation.title, ai_page_id: page.id, page_slug: page.slug, conv_slug: conversation.slug } ``` `POST /api/conversations` — add `slug`: ```ruby { id: conversation.id, title: conversation.title, ai_page_id: conversation.ai_page_id, slug: conversation.slug } ``` ## Verification 1. `./ai.rb db:migrate` — adds slug column 2. `./ai.rb server` — starts clean 3. Navigate to `/` — redirects to most recent canvas slug or shows home 4. Click `+` in footer → new canvas tab + conversation, URL updates to `/canvas-slug/chat-slug` 5. Add a weather widget via context menu → appears via canvas SSE 6. Click `+` on conversation level → new chat tab, URL updates 7. Send message → response arrives via single canvas SSE 8. Open second canvas from sidebar → second tab, URL updates 9. Switch between canvases/conversations → URL reflects state, browser back works 10. Copy URL, open in new tab → correct canvas + chat loads 11. Refresh → tabs restored from sessionStorage 12. Check thread usage: only 1 SSE per open canvas, not per conversation

1→# frozen_string_literal: true
     2→
     3→module Ai
     4→  module Tools
     5→    class UpdateCanvasTool < FastMcp::Tool
     6→      tool_name 'update_canvas'
     7→      description 'Update the canvas area for the current conversation with HTML content. The canvas is a large display area above the chat that can show rich content like dashboards, reports, or interactive pages. Creates a named AiPage if none exists.'
     8→
     9→      arguments do
    10→        required(:html).filled(:string).description('HTML content to display in the canvas')
    11→        optional(:title).filled(:string).description('Canvas page title (used when creating a new canvas page)')
    12→        optional(:conversation_id).filled(:integer).description('Conversation ID (defaults to current)')
    13→        optional(:mode).filled(:string).description('How to update: "replace" (default) replaces all content, "append" adds to existing content')
    14→      end
    15→
    16→      def call(html:, title: nil, conversation_id: nil, mode: 'replace')
    17→        conversation = if conversation_id
    18→          Ai::Conversation.find(conversation_id)
    19→        elsif ENV['CONVERSATION_ID']
    20→          Ai::Conversation.find(ENV['CONVERSATION_ID'])
    21→        else
    22→          Ai::Conversation.last
    23→        end
    24→
    25→        unless conversation
    26→          return { success: false, error: 'No conversation found' }
    27→        end
    28→
    29→        # Auto-create an AiPage if conversation has none
    30→        page = conversation.ai_page
    31→        unless page
    32→          page_title = title || conversation.title || 'Canvas'
    33→          page = Ai::AiPage.create!(
    34→            title: page_title,
    35→            content: '',
    36→            status: 'published',
    37→            published_at: Time.current
    38→          )
    39→          conversation.update!(ai_page: page)
    40→        end
    41→
    42→        # Update page content
    43→        if mode == 'append'
    44→          page.update!(content: (page.content || '') + html)
    45→        else
    46→          page.update!(content: html)
    47→        end
    48→
    49→        # Broadcast to ALL conversations sharing this page
    50→        action = mode == 'append' ? 'append' : 'update'
    51→        target = "canvas-page-#{page.id}"
    52→        stream_html = "<turbo-stream action=\"#{action}\" target=\"#{target}\"><template>#{html}</template></turbo-stream>"
    53→
    54→        Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:#{page.id}", stream_html)
    55→
    56→        { success: true, mode: mode, conversation_id: conversation.id, ai_page_id: page.id, slug: page.slug }
    57→      rescue => e
    58→        { success: false, error: e.message }
    59→      end
    60→    end
    61→  end
    62→end
    63→

I now have a thorough picture of the entire canvas component system. Let me compile the complete analysis. --- Here is the full lifecycle of the canvas component system in ai.rb. --- ## 1. The Data Model **File:** `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/ai/models/canvas_component.rb` **Migration:** `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/workspace/migrations/20260218000001_create_canvas_components.rb` The `CanvasComponent` model has these columns: | Column | Type | Default | Notes | |---|---|---|---| | `ai_page_id` | integer | (FK) | Belongs to an AiPage (the canvas page) | | `component_type` | string | `'card'` | Just a string tag; no type dispatch happens on it | | `content` | text | nil | Raw HTML — the widget's entire rendered content | | `x`, `y` | float | 0 | Absolute pixel position on the infinite canvas | | `width` | float | 320 | Width in pixels | | `height` | float | nil | null means auto-height | | `z_index` | integer | 0 | Layer order | | `metadata` | json | `{}` | Arbitrary key/value bag; not used by any framework code yet | The migration also added `canvas_state: json` to `ai_pages`, though this isn't used by component rendering — it's returned by `get_canvas` for the agent's context. The `as_canvas_json` method serializes everything to a flat hash used by the REST API and MCP tools. There are no polymorphic types, no type-specific subclasses, and no type-specific rendering logic. `component_type` is purely a label. It's stored and returned but the browser renders all components identically. --- ## 2. Widget Types — The Current Reality There is only one component type in practice right now: `"card"`. The weather widget uses `component_type: "weather"` as a label, but it renders exactly the same way as a card — as a `.canvas-component` div containing a `.canvas-component-content` div with raw HTML. The system is entirely type-agnostic at the rendering layer. There is no `switch(component_type)` anywhere. All components get the same HTML shell; the `type` is just metadata for the agent (and potentially for future extensions). --- ## 3. Weather Widget — Full Creation Lifecycle **Step 1: User right-clicks on the canvas** In `canvas_controller.js`, `onContextMenu` fires. Since no `.canvas-component` is found under the cursor, it calls `showCanvasMenu()` with world-space coordinates (screen position adjusted for pan and scale). **Step 2: Menu renders** The `canvasMenuItems` array is iterated to build buttons. "Add Weather Widget" (icon ☀️) maps to `this.addWeatherWidget(wx, wy)`. **Step 3: `addWeatherWidget` calls `createComponent`** ```js addWeatherWidget(x, y) { this.createComponent({ component_type: "weather", content: this.weatherWidgetHtml(), x, y, width: 280 }) } ``` `weatherWidgetHtml()` is a hardcoded template string with static values: "Curitiba, BR", "22°C", "68% humidity", etc. There is no live data fetch at all — the weather widget is decorative/demo content. **Step 4: `createComponent` POSTs to the API** ```js fetch(`/api/pages/${pageId}/components`, { method: "POST", headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" }, body: JSON.stringify(attrs) }) ``` **Step 5: Route handler creates the record** (`web/app.rb`, line ~321-348) ```ruby r.on 'components' do r.is do r.post do body = JSON.parse(r.body.read) rescue r.params component = page.canvas_components.create!( component_type: body['component_type'] || 'card', content: body['content'] || '', x: body['x']&.to_f || 0, ... ) ``` **Step 6: Route handler broadcasts Turbo Stream** ```ruby style = "left:#{component.x}px;top:#{component.y}px;width:#{component.width}px;" html = <<~HTML
#{component.content}
HTML turbo = " " TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:#{page.id}", turbo) ``` The route also returns `component.as_canvas_json` as the HTTP response body (for the calling JS), though the JS doesn't use the response for rendering — the Turbo Stream does the DOM insertion. --- ## 4. Turbo Stream Broadcasts **SSE stream endpoint:** `GET /api/pages/:id/stream` — subscribed via `sse_stream("canvas:#{page.id}")` **TurboBroadcast channel:** `"canvas:#{page.id}"` — all tabs viewing the same page receive updates. Three broadcast patterns are used: | Operation | Turbo action | Target | |---|---|---| | Create | `append` | `canvas-components-{page_id}` | | Update (MCP) | `replace` | `canvas-component-{id}` | | Delete | `remove` | `canvas-component-{id}` | The PATCH route (`/api/pages/:id/components/:component_id`) does NOT broadcast — it silently updates the DB and returns JSON. This is used for position saves and inline edits, which are already reflected in the local DOM optimistically. The MCP `update_canvas_component` tool DOES broadcast a `replace` turbo stream, so agent-initiated updates push to the browser. --- ## 5. canvas_controller.js — Full Behavior Breakdown **File:** `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/web/public/js/controllers/canvas_controller.js` This is a Stimulus controller with `data-controller="canvas"` and `data-canvas-page-id-value="..."`. ### Initialization - Grabs `.canvas-world` as the pannable/zoomable layer - Sets up mouse, touch, wheel, dblclick, contextmenu, keydown event listeners - Attaches a `MutationObserver` on `.canvas-world` — when the Turbo Stream appends a `.canvas-component` node, `initComponent(node)` runs automatically - Calls `initComponent` on all existing components - Exposes itself as `window.canvasController` for external access ### initComponent ```js initComponent(el) { el.style.zIndex = el.dataset.z || 0 } ``` That's it. Just sets `z-index` from `data-z`. No type-based initialization, no widget-specific setup. ### Pan and Drag - Left-click on `.canvas-component` → drag the component (updates CSS `left`/`top`) - Left-click on canvas background/world/dot-grid → pan the world layer - On drag end, calls `saveComponentPosition` which PATCHes x/y to `/api/pages/:id/components/:id` - Touch events mirror mouse events (single-touch only) ### Zoom - Mouse wheel: zoom toward cursor (min 10%, max 300%) using CSS transform on `.canvas-world` - Scroll lock mode: wheel pans instead of zooming ### Double-click to Edit - Finds the nearest `.canvas-component`, makes `.canvas-component-content` `contentEditable=true` - On blur or Escape: calls `finishEditing` which PATCHes the `innerHTML` via form-encoded body: ``` PATCH /api/pages/{pageId}/components/{compId} content= ``` - No broadcast from the PATCH — other clients won't see inline edits in real time. ### Context Menu Two registries, both extensible via `window.canvasController.canvasMenuItems.push(...)`: **Canvas-level menu** (right-click on empty space): - "Add Note" → `card` component with placeholder text, 240px wide - "Add Weather Widget" → `weather` component, 280px wide, static HTML - "Scroll Lock: On/Off" → toggles pan-on-scroll mode - "Reset View" → resets pan and zoom **Component-level menu** (right-click on a component): - "Chat about this" → creates a new `Conversation` linked to the page, opens a chat panel, prefills the textarea with `[Re: canvas widget #id]\n""` - "Duplicate" → GETs the component JSON, then POSTs a new component offset 24px right/down - "Delete" → removes from DOM immediately (optimistic), then sends `DELETE /api/pages/:id/components/:id` --- ## 6. Widget-Specific JS Behavior There is none. Every component, regardless of `component_type`, goes through the same `initComponent` (which just sets z-index). No type dispatch. The weather widget has no live data, no refresh timer, no fetch on init. It is purely static HTML. --- ## 7. MCP Tools **File locations:** - `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` - `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` - `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/ai/tools/remove_canvas_component_tool.rb` - `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/ai/tools/get_canvas_tool.rb` ### `add_canvas_component` Arguments: `content` (required), `component_type`, `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `z_index`, `metadata` Finds the page via `ENV['AI_PAGE_ID']` or `ENV['CONVERSATION_ID']`, creates the record, then broadcasts an `append` Turbo Stream to `canvas-components-{page_id}`. Returns `{ success, component_id, page_id }`. ### `update_canvas_component` Arguments: `component_id` (required), then any of `content`, `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `z_index`, `metadata` Finds component by ID (globally, no page scoping), applies only provided attrs, merges metadata rather than replacing it, then broadcasts a `replace` Turbo Stream to `canvas-component-{id}`. Returns `{ success, component: as_canvas_json }`. ### `remove_canvas_component` Arguments: `component_id` (required) Destroys the record, broadcasts a `remove` Turbo Stream. Returns `{ success, removed_id }`. ### `get_canvas` Arguments: `page_id` (optional) Returns all components as `as_canvas_json` arrays plus `canvas_state`. Used by the agent to understand current canvas state before adding components. There is also `update_canvas` (`/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/ai/tools/update_canvas_tool.rb`) which is a different, older-style tool — it sets the AiPage's `content` field (the freeform HTML page body, not the component system) and broadcasts to `canvas-page-{id}`. It coexists alongside the component system. --- ## 8. The Component PATCH Route ``` PATCH /api/pages/:page_id/components/:component_id ``` Handled at line 358–366 of `web/app.rb`: ```ruby r.patch do updates = {} %w[x y width height z_index].each do |attr| updates[attr] = r.params[attr].to_f if r.params[attr] end updates[:content] = r.params['content'] if r.params.key?('content') component.update!(updates) if updates.any? component.as_canvas_json end ``` - Accepts `application/x-www-form-urlencoded` (not JSON) - Numeric fields are coerced with `.to_f`; content is stored as-is - Returns the updated `as_canvas_json` but does NOT broadcast a Turbo Stream - Used for two things: saving drag position (x/y), and saving inline-edited content (content) --- ## Summary of the Full Lifecycle ``` Right-click canvas → canvasMenuItems[action](worldX, worldY) → addWeatherWidget(x, y) / addNote(x, y) → createComponent({ component_type, content, x, y, width }) → POST /api/pages/{pageId}/components (JSON body) → canvas_components.create! in DB → TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:{pageId}", ...) → SSE → browser receives turbo stream → Turbo appends
to canvas-world → MutationObserver fires → initComponent(el) → sets z-index → Component visible on canvas, draggable, right-clickable, double-click editable Drag component → onMouseUp → saveComponentPosition(el) → PATCH /api/pages/{pageId}/components/{id} (x=N&y=N) → DB updated, no broadcast Double-click to edit → contentEditable=true → blur/Escape → PATCH /api/pages/{pageId}/components/{id} (content=) → DB updated, no broadcast Agent uses add_canvas_component tool → MCP call → Ruby tool → DB create + TurboBroadcast → Same broadcast path as browser POST Agent uses update_canvas_component tool → MCP call → DB update + TurboBroadcast("replace") → Browser receives turbo-stream replace → DOM element swapped Agent uses remove_canvas_component tool → MCP call → DB destroy + TurboBroadcast("remove") → Browser receives turbo-stream remove → DOM element gone ```

Design a self-contained widget package system for a canvas-based AI assistant app. The goal is that the AI agent can create unlimited widget types by swapping "component blocks" like legos — each widget is a self-contained package with its own rendering, behavior, and optional backend logic, but all share the same efficient Turbo Stream broadcast pipeline. ## Current State The app has an infinite canvas (FigJam-like) where components are stored as `CanvasComponent` records with fields: `component_type` (string), `content` (raw HTML text), `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `z_index`, `metadata` (JSON). Currently there is NO type dispatch anywhere: - All components render identically: `
{content}
` - `initComponent(el)` just sets z-index — no type-specific setup - The weather widget is just hardcoded HTML, no live data - MCP tools (add/update/remove_canvas_component) work with raw HTML content - Turbo Stream broadcasts are efficient: one SSE per canvas, append/replace/remove actions ## Requirements 1. **Self-contained widget packages** — each widget type should define its own rendering (HTML template), JS behavior (init, update, destroy), and optionally a backend data source (a Ruby class/method that returns data) 2. **AI-friendly** — the agent should be able to create new widget types by creating a single file (or a small set of files), not by modifying core canvas/chat code 3. **Turbo Stream efficient** — broadcasts must stay as-is (append/replace/remove raw HTML). No per-widget SSE channels. 4. **Metadata-driven** — widget config stored in `metadata` JSON. Content field holds rendered HTML. The widget's Ruby backend can re-render HTML from metadata when data changes. 5. **Lego blocks** — the AI reuses the same patterns. Creating a "stocks widget" should be nearly identical in structure to creating a "weather widget". 6. **Minimal framework code** — auto-discovery via convention (like existing MCP tools use ObjectSpace scanning) ## Existing Patterns to Follow - MCP tools in `ai/tools/` are auto-discovered via ObjectSpace scanning of `FastMcp::Tool` subclasses - Models in `ai/models/` follow ActiveRecord conventions - Stimulus controllers in `web/public/js/controllers/` are auto-loaded via `application.js` - The canvas_controller.js already has extensible menu registries: `canvasMenuItems` and `componentMenuItems` ## Key Files - `ai/models/canvas_component.rb` — the model - `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` — creates components via MCP - `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` — updates via MCP - `ai/tools/remove_canvas_component_tool.rb` — removes via MCP - `web/public/js/controllers/canvas_controller.js` — pan/zoom/drag/context menu/edit, MutationObserver for Turbo Stream DOM insertions - `web/app.rb` — REST routes for components (POST/PATCH/DELETE) - `web/public/css/style.css` — component CSS ## Constraints - Keep the single `canvas_components` table — no new tables per widget - Keep Turbo Stream broadcasts unchanged (append/replace/remove with raw HTML) - Widget JS must be auto-initialized when Turbo Stream appends the DOM node (MutationObserver already fires `initComponent`) - The system must work with zero widgets registered (graceful fallback to current behavior) - Must support widgets that are purely static (note card), widgets with client-side behavior (clock, timer), and widgets with server-side data (weather, stocks) Design the architecture: file layout, base classes, registration mechanism, rendering pipeline, and show concrete examples for 2-3 widget types. Focus on making this as simple and DRY as possible for the AI to extend.

     3→require 'monitor'
     4→
     5→module Ai
     6→  module Web
     7→    # In-memory pub/sub for delivering Turbo Streams over SSE.
     8→    # Works because ActiveJob async adapter runs in the same process.
     9→    module TurboBroadcast
    10→      extend MonitorMixin
    11→
    12→      @subscribers = Hash.new { |h, k| h[k] = [] }
    13→
    14→      class << self
    15→        def subscribe(channel, &block)
    16→          synchronize { @subscribers[channel] << block }
    17→          Ai.logger.info "[TurboBroadcast] Subscribed to #{channel} (#{@subscribers[channel].size} subscribers)"
    18→          block
    19→        end
    20→
    21→        def unsubscribe(channel, block)
    22→          synchronize { @subscribers[channel].delete(block) }
    23→          Ai.logger.info "[TurboBroadcast] Unsubscribed from #{channel} (#{@subscribers[channel].size} remaining)"
    24→        end
    25→

    27→          subs = synchronize { @subscribers[channel].dup }

Design a self-contained widget package system for a canvas-based AI assistant app. The goal is that the AI agent can create unlimited widget types by swapping "component blocks" like legos — each widget is a self-contained package with its own rendering, behavior, and optional backend logic, but all share the same efficient Turbo Stream broadcast pipeline. ## Current State The app has an infinite canvas (FigJam-like) where components are stored as `CanvasComponent` records with fields: `component_type` (string), `content` (raw HTML text), `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `z_index`, `metadata` (JSON). Currently there is NO type dispatch anywhere: - All components render identically: `
{content}
` - `initComponent(el)` just sets z-index — no type-specific setup - The weather widget is just hardcoded HTML, no live data - MCP tools (add/update/remove_canvas_component) work with raw HTML content - Turbo Stream broadcasts are efficient: one SSE per canvas, append/replace/remove actions ## Requirements 1. **Self-contained widget packages** — each widget type should define its own rendering (HTML template), JS behavior (init, update, destroy), and optionally a backend data source (a Ruby class/method that returns data) 2. **AI-friendly** — the agent should be able to create new widget types by creating a single file (or a small set of files), not by modifying core canvas/chat code 3. **Turbo Stream efficient** — broadcasts must stay as-is (append/replace/remove raw HTML). No per-widget SSE channels. 4. **Metadata-driven** — widget config stored in `metadata` JSON. Content field holds rendered HTML. The widget's Ruby backend can re-render HTML from metadata when data changes. 5. **Lego blocks** — the AI reuses the same patterns. Creating a "stocks widget" should be nearly identical in structure to creating a "weather widget". 6. **Minimal framework code** — auto-discovery via convention (like existing MCP tools use ObjectSpace scanning) ## Existing Patterns to Follow - MCP tools in `ai/tools/` are auto-discovered via ObjectSpace scanning of `FastMcp::Tool` subclasses - Models in `ai/models/` follow ActiveRecord conventions - Stimulus controllers in `web/public/js/controllers/` are auto-loaded via `application.js` - The canvas_controller.js already has extensible menu registries: `canvasMenuItems` and `componentMenuItems` ## Key Files - `ai/models/canvas_component.rb` — the model - `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` — creates components via MCP - `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` — updates via MCP - `ai/tools/remove_canvas_component_tool.rb` — removes via MCP - `web/public/js/controllers/canvas_controller.js` — pan/zoom/drag/context menu/edit, MutationObserver for Turbo Stream DOM insertions - `web/app.rb` — REST routes for components (POST/PATCH/DELETE) - `web/public/css/style.css` — component CSS ## Constraints - Keep the single `canvas_components` table — no new tables per widget - Keep Turbo Stream broadcasts unchanged (append/replace/remove with raw HTML) - Widget JS must be auto-initialized when Turbo Stream appends the DOM node (MutationObserver already fires `initComponent`) - The system must work with zero widgets registered (graceful fallback to current behavior) - Must support widgets that are purely static (note card), widgets with client-side behavior (clock, timer), and widgets with server-side data (weather, stocks) Design the architecture: file layout, base classes, registration mechanism, rendering pipeline, and show concrete examples for 2-3 widget types. Focus on making this as simple and DRY as possible for the AI to extend.

I now have a complete picture of the codebase. Here is the full architecture design. --- ## Widget Package System -- Architecture Design ### Core Concept A **widget** is a self-contained Ruby class in `ai/widgets/` that declares how to render HTML from metadata, optionally how to fetch fresh data, and optionally what JS behavior it needs. The system uses the same ObjectSpace auto-discovery pattern already used by MCP tools and skills. Widget classes are the single source of truth -- the AI creates one Ruby file to define a new widget type. ### File Layout ``` ai/widgets/ base_widget.rb # Base class with shared rendering, auto-discovery note_widget.rb # Static: just renders HTML from metadata clock_widget.rb # Client-side: renders HTML + declares JS behavior weather_widget.rb # Server-side: fetches data, renders from metadata stocks_widget.rb # Server-side: fetches data, renders from metadata web/public/js/widgets/ widget_registry.js # Maps component_type -> { init, update, destroy } functions clock.js # Clock widget JS behavior (most widgets need no JS file -- only those with client-side behavior) ``` ### 1. Ruby Base Class: `ai/widgets/base_widget.rb` ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true module Ai module Widgets class BaseWidget class << self attr_reader :widget_type_name # DSL: declare the widget type string (matches component_type in DB) def widget_type(name) @widget_type_name = name.to_s end # Auto-discover all widget subclasses, keyed by widget_type def registry @registry ||= begin ObjectSpace.each_object(Class) .select { |c| c < BaseWidget && c.widget_type_name } .each_with_object({}) { |c, h| h[c.widget_type_name] = c } end end # Clear the cached registry (for development reload) def reset_registry! @registry = nil end # Look up a widget class by type string; returns nil for unknown types def for_type(type) registry[type.to_s] end # Default metadata schema (override in subclass for documentation) def default_metadata {} end end def initialize(component) @component = component @metadata = component.metadata || {} end # Render the inner HTML (goes inside .canvas-component-content). # Subclasses MUST override this. def render_content raise NotImplementedError end # Render the full component div (used by broadcast pipeline). # Adds data-widget-type attribute for JS dispatch. def render_component_html c = @component style = "left:#{c.x}px;top:#{c.y}px;width:#{c.width}px;" style += "height:#{c.height}px;" if c.height <<~HTML
#{render_content}
HTML end # Optional: fetch fresh data and update metadata. # Called by a scheduled refresh job or on-demand. # Returns true if data changed, false otherwise. def refresh_data! false end # Whether this widget type supports server-side refresh def self.refreshable? false end # Refresh interval in seconds (nil = no auto-refresh) def self.refresh_interval nil end end end end ``` ### 2. Loading Widgets in Bootstrap In `ai/bootstrap.rb`, add one line alongside the existing model/concern loading: ```ruby # Load widget definitions Dir[root.join('ai/widgets/**/*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f } ``` This follows the exact same pattern as concerns, models, and jobs. The `BaseWidget.registry` call uses ObjectSpace scanning, identical to the MCP tool discovery in `ai/mcp_server.rb`. ### 3. Centralized HTML Rendering: Modify `CanvasComponent` Model Add a `render_html` method to the model that delegates to the widget system with a graceful fallback: ```ruby # In ai/models/canvas_component.rb module Ai class CanvasComponent < ActiveRecord::Base # ... existing code ... # Render full component HTML, delegating to widget if registered def render_html widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) if widget_class widget_class.new(self).render_component_html else fallback_html end end # Render just the inner content def render_content widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) if widget_class widget_class.new(self).render_content else content end end private def fallback_html style = "left:#{x}px;top:#{y}px;width:#{width}px;" style += "height:#{height}px;" if height <<~HTML
#{content}
HTML end end end ``` ### 4. Update Broadcast Pipeline (DRY Up HTML Generation) The component HTML generation is currently duplicated in three places: `add_canvas_component_tool.rb`, `update_canvas_component_tool.rb`, and the `POST /api/pages/:id/components` route in `web/app.rb`. All three should call `component.render_html` instead of inlining the HTML. **In `add_canvas_component_tool.rb`**, replace the `component_html` method: ```ruby def broadcast_component_add(page, component) html = component.render_html turbo = "" broadcast_to_page(page, turbo) end ``` **In `update_canvas_component_tool.rb`**, same change: ```ruby def broadcast_component_replace(component) html = component.render_html turbo = "" Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:#{component.ai_page.id}", turbo) end ``` **In `web/app.rb`** POST route, replace the inline HTML with: ```ruby html = component.render_html turbo = "" TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:#{page.id}", turbo) ``` ### 5. Widget-Aware MCP Tools The existing `add_canvas_component` tool already accepts `metadata`. The key change is that when a widget type is known, the tool should use the widget's renderer instead of the raw `content` field. The tool flow becomes: 1. AI calls `add_canvas_component` with `component_type: "weather"`, `metadata: { city: "Curitiba", units: "metric" }`, and optionally `content: ""` (content can be empty since the widget renders from metadata). 2. After `create!`, the tool calls `component.render_html` which dispatches to `WeatherWidget`, which renders the HTML from metadata. 3. The rendered HTML is broadcast via Turbo Stream as before. For widgets with server-side data, the `content` field serves as a cache of the last-rendered HTML. The widget's `refresh_data!` method fetches new data, updates `metadata`, re-renders `content`, and broadcasts a replace. ### 6. JS Widget Registry: `web/public/js/widgets/widget_registry.js` ```javascript // Global widget behavior registry // Each entry: { init(el, metadata), update(el, metadata), destroy(el) } window.widgetBehaviors = {} // Register a widget behavior window.registerWidget = function(type, behavior) { window.widgetBehaviors[type] = behavior } ``` Loaded in `application.js` before the controllers: ```javascript import "/js/widgets/widget_registry.js" ``` ### 7. Update `initComponent` in `canvas_controller.js` The MutationObserver already calls `initComponent` for every new DOM node. Extend it to dispatch to widget behaviors: ```javascript initComponent(el) { el.style.zIndex = el.dataset.z || 0 // Widget behavior dispatch const widgetType = el.dataset.widgetType if (widgetType && window.widgetBehaviors?.[widgetType]?.init) { try { const metadata = JSON.parse(el.dataset.widgetMetadata || '{}') window.widgetBehaviors[widgetType].init(el, metadata) } catch (e) { console.warn(`[Canvas] Widget init failed for ${widgetType}:`, e) } } } ``` Add a matching destroy hook in `disconnect()` and when components are removed: ```javascript destroyComponent(el) { const widgetType = el.dataset.widgetType if (widgetType && window.widgetBehaviors?.[widgetType]?.destroy) { try { window.widgetBehaviors[widgetType].destroy(el) } catch (e) { console.warn(`[Canvas] Widget destroy failed for ${widgetType}:`, e) } } } ``` Also update `_renderCanvasComponent` in `chat_footer_controller.js` to pass `data-widget-type`: ```javascript _renderCanvasComponent(comp) { let style = `left:${comp.x}px;top:${comp.y}px;width:${comp.width}px;` if (comp.height) style += `height:${comp.height}px;` const meta = comp.metadata ? JSON.stringify(comp.metadata).replace(/"/g, '"') : '{}' return `
${comp.content || ''}
` } ``` ### 8. Concrete Widget Examples **Example 1: Note Widget (static, no JS, no server data)** `ai/widgets/note_widget.rb`: ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true module Ai module Widgets class NoteWidget < BaseWidget widget_type 'card' def self.default_metadata { text: 'Double-click to edit...' } end def render_content text = @metadata['text'] || @component.content "

#{text}

" end end end end ``` **Example 2: Clock Widget (client-side JS behavior, no server data)** `ai/widgets/clock_widget.rb`: ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true module Ai module Widgets class ClockWidget < BaseWidget widget_type 'clock' def self.default_metadata { timezone: 'America/Sao_Paulo', label: 'Curitiba' } end def render_content tz = @metadata['timezone'] || 'UTC' label = @metadata['label'] || tz <<~HTML
#{label}
--:--:--
HTML end end end end ``` `web/public/js/widgets/clock.js`: ```javascript import "/js/widgets/widget_registry.js" registerWidget('clock', { init(el, metadata) { const tz = metadata.timezone || 'UTC' const display = el.querySelector('[data-clock-display]') const dateEl = el.querySelector('[data-clock-date]') if (!display) return const tick = () => { const now = new Date() display.textContent = now.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { timeZone: tz, hour12: false }) if (dateEl) dateEl.textContent = now.toLocaleDateString('en-US', { timeZone: tz, weekday: 'short', month: 'short', day: 'numeric' }) } tick() el._clockInterval = setInterval(tick, 1000) }, destroy(el) { if (el._clockInterval) clearInterval(el._clockInterval) } }) ``` Load in `application.js`: ```javascript import "/js/widgets/clock.js" ``` **Example 3: Weather Widget (server-side data refresh)** `ai/widgets/weather_widget.rb`: ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true module Ai module Widgets class WeatherWidget < BaseWidget widget_type 'weather' def self.refreshable? true end def self.refresh_interval 1800 # 30 minutes end def self.default_metadata { city: 'Curitiba', country: 'BR', units: 'metric' } end def render_content data = @metadata city = data['city'] || 'Unknown' country = data['country'] || '' temp = data['temp'] || '--' feels_like = data['feels_like'] || '--' description = data['description'] || 'Loading...' humidity = data['humidity'] || '--' wind = data['wind'] || '--' uv = data['uv'] || '--' icon = data['icon'] || "\u2600\ufe0f" <<~HTML
#{city}, #{country}
#{description}
#{icon}
#{temp}°C Feels like #{feels_like}°
Humidity
#{humidity}%
Wind
#{wind} km/h
UV Index
#{uv}
HTML end def refresh_data! city = @metadata['city'] || 'Curitiba' # Fetch from weather API (using existing web_fetch or Net::HTTP) # Update metadata with fresh values # For now, placeholder: api_data = fetch_weather(city) return false unless api_data @component.update!( metadata: @metadata.merge(api_data), content: render_content # Cache rendered HTML ) true end private def fetch_weather(city) # Implementation would use OpenWeatherMap or similar API # Returns hash like { temp: 22, feels_like: 21, description: "Partly cloudy", ... } nil end end end end ``` ### 9. Widget Refresh Job A single background job that refreshes all refreshable widgets on their declared interval: `ai/jobs/widget_refresh_job.rb`: ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true module Ai module Jobs class WidgetRefreshJob < ApplicationJob def perform Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.registry.each do |type, widget_class| next unless widget_class.refreshable? && widget_class.refresh_interval components = CanvasComponent.where(component_type: type) components.find_each do |component| widget = widget_class.new(component) if widget.refresh_data! # Broadcast the updated HTML html = widget.render_component_html turbo = "" Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:#{component.ai_page_id}", turbo) end end end end end end end ``` Register in the scheduler (`ai/scheduler.rb`) with something like: ```ruby scheduler.every '5m' do Ai::Jobs::WidgetRefreshJob.perform_later end ``` ### 10. Context Menu Auto-Registration To make the context menu extensible without modifying canvas_controller.js, widgets can declare a `menu_item` in their Ruby class, and the canvas JSON API can return available widget types. Then the canvas controller fetches the list once and populates the menu dynamically. Add to `web/app.rb` a new endpoint: ```ruby r.on 'widget_types' do r.get do types = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.registry.map do |type, klass| { type: type, label: klass.respond_to?(:menu_label) ? klass.menu_label : type.titleize, icon: klass.respond_to?(:menu_icon) ? klass.menu_icon : nil } end { widget_types: types } end end ``` And in `canvas_controller.js`, on connect, fetch `/api/widget_types` and dynamically add menu items before the separator. This way adding a new widget Ruby file automatically adds it to the context menu. ### Summary of Changes by File | File | Change | Type | |------|--------|------| | `ai/widgets/base_widget.rb` | New base class with registry, rendering, refresh | **New** | | `ai/widgets/note_widget.rb` | Note/card widget | **New** | | `ai/widgets/clock_widget.rb` | Clock widget | **New** | | `ai/widgets/weather_widget.rb` | Weather widget with refresh | **New** | | `web/public/js/widgets/widget_registry.js` | JS behavior registry | **New** | | `web/public/js/widgets/clock.js` | Clock tick behavior | **New** | | `ai/jobs/widget_refresh_job.rb` | Periodic data refresh | **New** | | `ai/models/canvas_component.rb` | Add `render_html`, `render_content` methods | **Modify** | | `ai/bootstrap.rb` | Add `Dir[root.join('ai/widgets/**/*.rb')]` load line | **Modify** | | `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Use `component.render_html` instead of inline HTML | **Modify** | | `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Use `component.render_html` instead of inline HTML | **Modify** | | `web/app.rb` | Use `component.render_html` in POST route; add `/api/widget_types` | **Modify** | | `web/public/js/controllers/canvas_controller.js` | Extend `initComponent` with widget dispatch; add `destroyComponent` | **Modify** | | `web/public/js/controllers/chat_footer_controller.js` | Add `data-widget-type` and `data-widget-metadata` to rendered HTML | **Modify** | | `web/public/js/application.js` | Import widget_registry.js and widget JS files | **Modify** | ### How the AI Creates a New Widget To create a "Stocks Widget", the AI would: 1. Create `ai/widgets/stocks_widget.rb` with `widget_type 'stocks'`, `render_content` using metadata keys like `symbol`, `price`, `change`, and `refreshable? true`. 2. Optionally create `web/public/js/widgets/stocks.js` if it needs client-side behavior (e.g., sparkline animation). 3. No other files need to change. Ruby Base Class: `ai/widgets/base_widget.rb` ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true module Ai module Widgets class BaseWidget class << self attr_reader :widget_type_name # DSL: declare the widget type string (matches component_type in DB) def widget_type(name) @widget_type_name = name.to_s end # Auto-discover all widget subclasses, keyed by widget_type def registry @registry ||= begin ObjectSpace.each_object(Class) .select { |c| c < BaseWidget && c.widget_type_name } .each_with_object({}) { |c, h| h[c.widget_type_name] = c } end end # Clear the cached registry (for development reload) def reset_registry! @registry = nil end # Look up a widget class by type string; returns nil for unknown types def for_type(type) registry[type.to_s] end # Default metadata schema (override in subclass for documentation) def default_metadata {} end end def initialize(component) @component = component @metadata = component.metadata || {} end # Render the inner HTML (goes inside .canvas-component-content). # Subclasses MUST override this. def render_content raise NotImplementedError end # Render the full component div (used by broadcast pipeline). # Adds data-widget-type attribute for JS dispatch. def render_component_html c = @component style = "left:#{c.x}px;top:#{c.y}px;width:#{c.width}px;" style += "height:#{c.height}px;" if c.height <<~HTML
#{render_content}
HTML end # Optional: fetch fresh data and update metadata. # Called by a scheduled refresh job or on-demand. # Returns true if data changed, false otherwise. def refresh_data! false end # Whether this widget type supports server-side refresh def self.refreshable? false end # Refresh interval in seconds (nil = no auto-refresh) def self.refresh_interval nil end end end end ``` ### 2. Loading Widgets in Bootstrap In `ai/bootstrap.rb`, add one line alongside the existing model/concern loading: ```ruby # Load widget definitions Dir[root.join('ai/widgets/**/*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f } ``` This follows the exact same pattern as concerns, models, and jobs. The `BaseWidget.registry` call uses ObjectSpace scanning, identical to the MCP tool discovery in `ai/mcp_server.rb`. ### 3. Centralized HTML Rendering: Modify `CanvasComponent` Model Add a `render_html` method to the model that delegates to the widget system with a graceful fallback: ```ruby # In ai/models/canvas_component.rb module Ai class CanvasComponent < ActiveRecord::Base # ... existing code ... # Render full component HTML, delegating to widget if registered def render_html widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) if widget_class widget_class.new(self).render_component_html else fallback_html end end # Render just the inner content def render_content widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) if widget_class widget_class.new(self).render_content else content end end private def fallback_html style = "left:#{x}px;top:#{y}px;width:#{width}px;" style += "height:#{height}px;" if height <<~HTML
#{content}
HTML end end end ``` ### 4. Update Broadcast Pipeline (DRY Up HTML Generation) The component HTML generation is currently duplicated in three places: `add_canvas_component_tool.rb`, `update_canvas_component_tool.rb`, and the `POST /api/pages/:id/components` route in `web/app.rb`. Widget-Aware MCP Tools The existing `add_canvas_component` tool already accepts `metadata`. The key change is that when a widget type is known, the tool should use the widget's renderer instead of the raw `content` field. The tool flow becomes: 1. AI calls `add_canvas_component` with `component_type: "weather"`, `metadata: { city: "Curitiba", units: "metric" }`, and optionally `content: ""` (content can be empty since the widget renders from metadata). 2. #{label}

HTML end end end end ``` `web/public/js/widgets/clock.js`: ```javascript import "/js/widgets/widget_registry.js" registerWidget('clock', { init(el, metadata) { const tz = metadata.timezone || 'UTC' const display = el.querySelector('[data-clock-display]') const dateEl = el.querySelector('[data-clock-date]') if (!display) return const tick = () => { const now = new Date() display.textContent = now.toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { timeZone: tz, hour12: false }) if (dateEl) dateEl.textContent = now.toLocaleDateString('en-US', { timeZone: tz, weekday: 'short', month: 'short', day: 'numeric' }) } tick() el._clockInterval = setInterval(tick, 1000) }, destroy(el) { if (el._clockInterval) clearInterval(el._clockInterval) } }) ``` Load in `application.js`: ```javascript import "/js/widgets/clock.js" ``` **Example 3: Weather Widget (server-side data refresh)** `ai/widgets/weather_widget.rb`: ```ruby # frozen_string_literal: true module Ai module Widgets class WeatherWidget < BaseWidget widget_type 'weather' def self.refreshable? true end def self.refresh_interval 1800 # 30 minutes end def self.default_metadata { city: 'Curitiba', country: 'BR', units: 'metric' } end def render_content data = @metadata city = data['city'] || 'Unknown' country = data['country'] || '' temp = data['temp'] || '--' feels_like = data['feels_like'] || '--' description = data['description'] || 'Loading...' humidity = data['humidity'] || '--' wind = data['wind'] || '--' uv = data['uv'] || '--' icon = data['icon'] || "\u2600\ufe0f" <<~HTML

require 'bundler/setup'
require 'pathname'
require 'active_record'
require 'logger'

module Ai
  class << self
    attr_accessor :root, :logger

    def env
      ENV['AI_ENV'] || ENV['RACK_ENV'] || 'development'
    end

    def load!
      @root = Pathname.new(__dir__).parent
      @logger = Logger.new($stdout)
      @logger.level = env == 'production' ? Logger::INFO : Logger::DEBUG

      # Load dotenv for environment variables
      require 'dotenv'
      Dotenv.load("#{root}/.env.#{env}", "#{root}/.env")

      # Load core components
      load_core_components
    end

    private

    def load_core_components
      # Core framework files (order matters)
      require_relative 'database'
      require_relative 'agent'
      require_relative 'scheduler'
      require_relative 'skill_loader'
      require_relative 'message_router'
      require_relative 'whatsapp'
      require_relative 'mcp_server'

      # Load concerns and models
      Dir[root.join('ai/concerns/**/*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f }
      Dir[root.join('ai/models/**/*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f }

      # Load jobs
      require_relative 'jobs/application_job'
      Dir[root.join('ai/jobs/**/*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f unless f.include?('application_job') }

      # Configure ActiveJob queue adapter
      require_relative 'queue'

      # Connect to database if configured
      Ai::Database.connect! if Ai::Database.configured?
    end
  end
end

# Auto-load the framework
Ai.load!
