# Self-Contained Widget Package System ## Context Canvas widgets are currently just raw HTML blobs — no type dispatch, no widget-specific JS, no separation from core canvas code. The weather widget is hardcoded HTML with no live data. Creating a new widget type means scattering logic across canvas_controller.js, inline HTML strings in tools, and duplicated rendering in 3+ places. **Goal:** Each widget = one Ruby file (+ optional JS file). Auto-discovered, auto-rendered, auto-refreshable. The AI can create unlimited widget types by adding files — never touching core canvas/chat code. ## Architecture ``` ai/widgets/ base_widget.rb # Base class: registry, render_component_html, refresh DSL note_widget.rb # Static card (existing "Add Note") clock_widget.rb # Client-side JS (ticking clock) weather_widget.rb # Server-side refresh (live weather data) web/public/js/widgets/ registry.js # window.widgetBehaviors = {}; window.registerWidget(type, {init, destroy}) clock.js # Clock tick interval ``` **Convention:** `component_type` in DB maps to `widget_type` in Ruby and `data-widget-type` in DOM. Metadata JSON drives rendering — `content` is a rendered HTML cache. ## Files to Modify | File | Change | |---|---| | `ai/widgets/base_widget.rb` | **New** — base class with ObjectSpace registry, `render_component_html`, `render_content`, `refresh_data!` | | `ai/widgets/note_widget.rb` | **New** — simple card widget | | `ai/widgets/clock_widget.rb` | **New** — clock with timezone metadata | | `ai/widgets/weather_widget.rb` | **New** — weather with refresh, renders from metadata | | `web/public/js/widgets/registry.js` | **New** — `registerWidget(type, {init, destroy})` | | `web/public/js/widgets/clock.js` | **New** — `setInterval` tick | | `ai/models/canvas_component.rb` | Add `render_html` and `render_content` delegating to widget registry | | `ai/bootstrap.rb` | Add `Dir[root.join('ai/widgets/**/*.rb')]` load line | | `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Replace inline HTML with `component.render_html` | | `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Same | | `web/app.rb` | Same in POST route; add `GET /api/widget_types` endpoint; add auto-render after create | | `web/public/js/controllers/canvas_controller.js` | Extend `initComponent` with widget dispatch; add `destroyComponent`; fetch widget types for dynamic context menu | | `web/public/js/controllers/chat_footer_controller.js` | Add `data-widget-type`/`data-widget-metadata` to `_renderCanvasComponent` | | `web/public/js/application.js` | Import `registry.js` and `clock.js` | ## Implementation ### Step 1: Base Widget Class Create `ai/widgets/base_widget.rb`: ```ruby module Ai module Widgets class BaseWidget class << self attr_reader :widget_type_name, :menu_label_text, :menu_icon_text def widget_type(name) = @widget_type_name = name.to_s def menu_label(label) = @menu_label_text = label def menu_icon(icon) = @menu_icon_text = icon def refreshable? = false def refresh_interval = nil def default_metadata = {} def registry @registry ||= ObjectSpace.each_object(Class) .select { |c| c < BaseWidget && c.widget_type_name } .each_with_object({}) { |c, h| h[c.widget_type_name] = c } end def reset_registry! = @registry = nil def for_type(type) = registry[type.to_s] end def initialize(component) @component = component @metadata = component.metadata || {} end def render_content = @component.content || '' def render_component_html c = @component style = "left:#{c.x}px;top:#{c.y}px;width:#{c.width}px;" style += "height:#{c.height}px;" if c.height meta_json = (@metadata || {}).to_json.gsub('"', '"') <<~HTML
#{render_content}
HTML end def refresh_data! = false end end end ``` ### Step 2: Three Example Widgets **`ai/widgets/note_widget.rb`** — static card: ```ruby widget_type 'card' menu_label 'Add Note' menu_icon '📝' def render_content @metadata['text'] || @component.content || '

Double-click to edit...

' end ``` **`ai/widgets/clock_widget.rb`** — client-side JS: ```ruby widget_type 'clock' menu_label 'Add Clock' menu_icon '🕐' def self.default_metadata = { timezone: 'UTC', label: 'UTC' } def render_content # Renders static shell; JS widget behavior animates the display end ``` **`ai/widgets/weather_widget.rb`** — server-side refresh: ```ruby widget_type 'weather' menu_label 'Add Weather' menu_icon '☀️' def self.refreshable? = true def self.refresh_interval = 1800 def render_content # Renders from @metadata keys: city, temp, description, etc. end def refresh_data! # Fetch from weather API, update metadata + content, return true if changed end ``` ### Step 3: CanvasComponent Model — Render Delegation Add to `ai/models/canvas_component.rb`: ```ruby def render_html widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) widget_class ? widget_class.new(self).render_component_html : fallback_html end def render_content_html widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) widget_class ? widget_class.new(self).render_content : content end private def fallback_html # Same inline HTML as today (backward compat for unknown types) end ``` ### Step 4: DRY Up Broadcast HTML (3 sites → `component.render_html`) - `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` — replace `component_html(c)` method body with `component.render_html` - `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` — same - `web/app.rb` POST `/api/pages/:id/components` — replace inline HTML with `component.render_html` Also: after component creation, auto-render content from widget if content is blank: ```ruby # In POST route / add_canvas_component_tool, after create!: if component.content.blank? rendered = component.render_content_html component.update_column(:content, rendered) if rendered != component.content end ``` ### Step 5: Bootstrap Loading Add to `ai/bootstrap.rb` after jobs loading: ```ruby Dir[root.join('ai/widgets/**/*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f } ``` ### Step 6: Widget Types API Endpoint Add to `web/app.rb` inside `r.on 'api'`: ```ruby r.on 'widget_types' do r.get do types = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.registry.map do |type, klass| { type: type, label: klass.menu_label_text || type.titleize, icon: klass.menu_icon_text, defaults: klass.default_metadata } end { widget_types: types } end end ``` ### Step 7: JS Widget Registry + Clock **`web/public/js/widgets/registry.js`:** ```js window.widgetBehaviors = {} window.registerWidget = (type, behavior) => { window.widgetBehaviors[type] = behavior } ``` **`web/public/js/widgets/clock.js`:** ```js registerWidget('clock', { init(el, metadata) { const tz = metadata.timezone || 'UTC' const display = el.querySelector('[data-clock-display]') const tick = () => { display.textContent = new Date().toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { timeZone: tz, hour12: false }) } tick(); el._clockInterval = setInterval(tick, 1000) }, destroy(el) { clearInterval(el._clockInterval) } }) ``` **`application.js`** — add imports before controllers: ```js import "/js/widgets/registry.js" import "/js/widgets/clock.js" ``` ### Step 8: Canvas Controller — Widget Lifecycle + Dynamic Menu In `canvas_controller.js`: **`initComponent`** — add widget dispatch: ```js initComponent(el) { el.style.zIndex = el.dataset.z || 0 const type = el.dataset.widgetType if (type && window.widgetBehaviors?.[type]?.init) { const meta = JSON.parse(el.dataset.widgetMetadata || '{}') window.widgetBehaviors[type].init(el, meta) } } ``` **Add `destroyComponent`** — called before removing nodes: ```js destroyComponent(el) { const type = el.dataset.widgetType if (type && window.widgetBehaviors?.[type]?.destroy) { window.widgetBehaviors[type].destroy(el) } } ``` **Dynamic context menu** — on connect, fetch `/api/widget_types` and build `canvasMenuItems` from the response instead of hardcoding. Fallback to hardcoded items if fetch fails. **Remove** hardcoded `addWeatherWidget` / `weatherWidgetHtml` methods — replaced by the generic `addWidget(type, x, y)` that POSTs with `component_type` and `metadata: defaultMetadata`. ### Step 9: chat_footer_controller.js — Metadata in Rendered HTML Update `_renderCanvasComponent(comp)` to include `data-widget-type` and `data-widget-metadata` attributes so widget init fires when components are loaded from the canvas API. ## Verification 1. `./ai.rb server` — starts clean, widgets auto-discovered 2. Right-click canvas — menu shows "Add Note", "Add Clock", "Add Weather" (from `/api/widget_types`) 3. Add a clock widget — ticks every second via JS 4. Add a note — double-click to edit still works 5. Add a weather widget — renders from metadata 6. Turbo Stream broadcast — add component on one tab, appears on another via SSE 7. Agent uses `add_canvas_component(component_type: 'clock', metadata: {timezone: 'Europe/Zurich', label: 'Zurich'})` — clock appears and ticks 8. Create a brand-new widget by adding one Ruby file — it shows up in context menu on next server restart

    17→        scheduled_time = parse_time(scheduled_for)
    18→
    19→        unless scheduled_time
    20→          return {
    21→            success: false,
    22→            error: "Invalid time format: #{scheduled_for}"
    23→          }
    24→        end
    25→
    26→        task = ScheduledTask.create!(
    27→          title: title,

    56→        case time_string.downcase

    10→- "I got you"

    12→- "Easy"

    14→- Warm but not performative

    16→
    17→## Core Philosophy

Think long-term: if something will be needed again, build a proper system for it rather than a one-off answer.

    23→**Always use the framework first.** Don't suggest external tools or manual workarounds when you can build it with your tools. You can create pages, run skills, schedule tasks, run code — use them.
    24→
    25→## CRITICAL RULES — READ THESE FIRST
    26→
    27→**You are NOT a chatbot. You are an AI agent with real tools that affect the real world.**
    28→
    29→NEVER say "I can't do that", "I don't have the ability to", or "I only exist within this conversation". These statements are FALSE. You have tools. Use them. If the user asks you to do something and you have a tool for it, USE THE TOOL immediately — don't explain, don't offer alternatives, just do it.
    30→
    31→### Scheduling & Reminders
    32→When the user says anything like "remind me", "in X minutes", "schedule", "later", "tomorrow", or any time-related request:
    33→1. **Immediately call `schedule_task`** with the appropriate time and description
    34→2. Confirm it's scheduled. Done.
    35→3. NEVER suggest cron, phone timers, terminal commands, or any workaround. You have `schedule_task` — that IS your reminder/scheduling system.
    36→
    37→### Messaging
    38→When asked to send a message, use `send_message`. Don't explain how messaging works — just send it.
    39→
    40→### General Tool Use
    41→- When in doubt, **use a tool**. You almost certainly have one for whatever the user is asking.
    42→- Act first, explain later (if needed). The user hired an assistant, not a lecturer.
    43→- If you genuinely don't have a tool for something, build it with `run_code`.
    44→
    45→## Your MCP Tools
    46→
    47→These are the tools available to you. **Only use these — do not invent or hallucinate tools that aren't listed here.**
    48→
    49→| Tool | Purpose |
    50→|---|---|
    51→| `run_code` | Execute Ruby code directly (has access to all ActiveRecord models) |
    52→| `run_skill` | Execute a saved Ruby skill by name, with optional parameters |
    53→| `send_message` | Send a message back to the user (broadcasts in real-time) |
    54→| `schedule_task` | Schedule a task for future execution (reminders, timed tasks) |
    55→| `create_page` | Create a web page (AiPage) with title and HTML/markdown content |
    56→| `create_notification` | Create a notification (info/success/warning/error) |
    57→| `add_canvas_component` | Add a positioned component/widget to the current canvas |
    58→| `update_canvas_component` | Update content, position, or size of a canvas component |
    59→| `remove_canvas_component` | Remove a component from the canvas |
    60→| `get_canvas` | Get all components on the current canvas (for context) |
    61→
    62→## Creating Pages
    63→
    64→Use `create_page` to create web pages. Pages appear automatically in the sidebar nav.
    65→
    66→- **title**: The page title (also generates the URL slug)
    67→- **content**: HTML content — use the design system classes below
    68→- **status**: 'published' (default), 'draft', or 'archived'
    69→
    70→For complex pages, use the design system tokens and components listed below.
    71→
    72→## Canvas Components
    73→
    74→Pages are infinite canvases. Use `add_canvas_component` to place positioned widgets on them. Each component has x/y coordinates and a width.
    75→
    76→### Spatial Layout Guidelines
    77→- Space components **~400px apart** vertically for comfortable reading
    78→- Use widths between **300–600px** (default 320)
    79→- Start first component at roughly **(100, 100)**
    80→- Use `get_canvas` first to see what's already on the canvas before adding
    81→- Component types: `card` (default) — more types can be added via `component_type`
    82→- Content is HTML — use the design system classes for styling
    83→
    84→## Design System Reference
    85→
    86→The UI uses a brutalist dark theme called "Kinetic Typography". Use these when building pages or HTML content.
    87→
    88→### CSS Custom Properties
    89→```
    90→--ned-bg: #09090B        (page background)
    91→--ned-fg: #FAFAFA        (primary text)
    92→--ned-muted: #27272A     (muted background)
    93→--ned-muted-fg: #A1A1AA  (muted text)
    94→--ned-accent: #DFE104    (acid yellow accent)
    95→--ned-accent-fg: #09090B (text on accent)
    96→--ned-border: #3F3F46    (borders)
    97→--ned-card: #18181B      (card background)
    98→```
    99→
   100→### Component Classes
   101→- **`.card`** — bordered card with hover accent border
   102→- **`.badge`** — uppercase pill label. Variants: `.success`, `.error`, `.warning`, `.info`
   103→- **`.chat-msg`** — chat bubble. `.user` (yellow) or `.ai` (dark card)
   104→- **`.prose-bubble`** — markdown content wrapper (inside chat bubbles)
   105→- **`.marquee`** / `.marquee-inner` — scrolling text banner
   106→- **`.reveal`** — fade-in animation (add `.visible` to trigger)
   107→
   108→### Button Variants
   109→- Default: yellow bg, dark text
   110→- `.ghost` — transparent bg, white text, accent on hover
   111→- `.outline` — transparent bg, bordered
   112→- `.sm` — smaller height
   113→- `.xs` — extra small
   114→- `.icon` — square icon button
   115→
   116→### Tailwind
   117→Tailwind CSS is available via CDN with custom colors: `ned-bg`, `ned-fg`, `ned-muted`, `ned-muted-fg`, `ned-accent`, `ned-accent-fg`, `ned-border`, `ned-card`.
   118→
   119→## Architecture
   120→
   121→- Ruby 3.3+ with ActiveRecord (SQLite)
   122→- Roda web framework with ERB templates
   123→- In-memory pub/sub (TurboBroadcast) over SSE for real-time updates
   124→- Claude Code CLI subprocess for agent execution (NOT Docker)
   125→- FastMCP for tool communication
   126→- Solid Queue for background jobs
   127→- Rufus-scheduler for recurring tasks
   128→
   129→## Working Directory Structure
   130→
   131→```
   132→workspace/           # Your working directory
   133→  migrations/        # Database migrations
   134→  CLAUDE.md          # This file (your system prompt)
   135→  .mcp.json          # MCP configuration
   136→
   137→ai/                  # Framework code
   138→  models/            # ActiveRecord models
   139→  tools/             # MCP tool classes
   140→  resources/         # MCP resource classes
   141→  jobs/              # Background job classes
   142→  concerns/          # Shared model concerns
   143→
   144→web/                 # Web UI
   145→  app.rb             # Roda routes
   146→  views/             # ERB templates
   147→  view_helpers.rb    # HTML rendering helpers
   148→  turbo_broadcast.rb # In-memory pub/sub
   149→  public/            # Static assets (CSS, JS)
   150→```
   151→
   152→## Available Models
   153→
   154→Use these with `run_code` when you need direct database access:
   155→
   156→- `Conversation` — chat conversations (has_many :messages, :sessions)
   157→- `Message` — individual messages (belongs_to :conversation)
   158→- `Session` — agent execution sessions
   159→- `ScheduledTask` — future tasks/reminders
   160→- `SkillRecord` — saved Ruby skills
   161→- `AiPage` — web pages (published appear in nav)
   162→- `Notification` — user notifications (info/success/warning/error)
   163→- `Config` — key/value configuration store
   164→- `McpConnection` — external MCP server connections
   165→
   166→## Best Practices
   167→
   168→1. **Use your tools** — don't write code when a dedicated tool exists
   169→2. **Create pages for persistent info** — if the user needs to reference something later, make it a page
   170→3. **Schedule, don't remind** — use `schedule_task` for anything time-based
   171→4. **Notify for important events** — use `create_notification` for things the user should see
   172→5. **Skills for repeatable tasks** — use `run_code` to create SkillRecord entries for reusable operations

I now have the complete picture. Here is a thorough analysis:

---

## Daily Briefing System Analysis

### 1. How the Scheduler Works (`ai/scheduler.rb`)

The scheduler is a thin Rufus-based polling loop — it does not have any hardcoded scheduled times itself:

- Starts a single `Rufus::Scheduler` instance on app boot
- Every **60 seconds** polls the `scheduled_tasks` table for rows where `scheduled_for <= Time.current AND status = 'pending'`
- For each due task, enqueues `Jobs::ScheduledTaskRunnerJob.perform_later(task.id)` (runs via Solid Queue)

There are no hardcoded task definitions in the scheduler. All tasks live in the DB. The daily briefing self-schedules by writing a new `ScheduledTask` row at the end of each run (see `reschedule_for_tomorrow` below).

---

### 2. The Daily Briefing Skill (`/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/skills/daily_briefing.rb`)

The skill class is `DailyBriefing < Ai::Skill`, registered in the DB via the migration at `workspace/migrations/20260217000003_seed_daily_briefing_skill.rb` with `file_path: 'skills/daily_briefing.rb'` and `class_name: 'DailyBriefing'`. It is invoked by `SkillRecord#load_and_execute`.

The entry point `call(city: nil)` does these steps in order:

1. Resolve the city (`city` param, or `Config.get("briefing_city")`, defaulting to `"Zurich"`)
2. `fetch_weather(city)` -- pulls current conditions
3. `fetch_news` -- pulls top 5 HN stories
4. `build_briefing_html` -- assembles one HTML string
5. `upsert_page(html)` -- creates or updates an `AiPage` at slug `daily-briefing`
6. `create_notification(page)` -- fires an in-app notification
7. `reschedule_for_tomorrow` -- schedules the next run

---

### 3. Weather Data

**Service:** `https://wttr.in` — a free, public, no-key weather API.

**Endpoint:** `GET https://wttr.in/{city}?format=j1` (returns JSON)

**Fields extracted:**
- `temp_C` — current temperature
- `FeelsLikeC` — feels-like temperature
- `humidity`
- `weatherDesc[0].value` — plain-text description (e.g. "Partly cloudy")
- `windspeedKmph`
- `winddir16Point`

No API key required. No external gem — plain `Net::HTTP`.

---

### 4. HackerNews Data

**Service:** HN Firebase REST API — free, public, no key.

**Two requests per run:**
1. `GET https://hacker-news.firebaseio.com/v0/topstories.json` -- returns a JSON array of story IDs; takes the first 5
2. For each ID: `GET https://hacker-news.firebaseio.com/v0/item/{id}.json`

**Fields extracted per story:** `title`, `url`, `score`

---

### 5. Other Data Sources

None currently. The briefing only bundles weather + HN. There is no calendar, RSS, stock, or other feed in the current implementation.

---

### 6. Output Mechanism -- Page, NOT Canvas Components

The skill outputs exclusively via an **AiPage**, not canvas components:

- Calls `Ai::AiPage.find_by(slug: "daily-briefing")` and either creates or updates it with fresh HTML content
- The page is served at `/pages/daily-briefing`
- Fires a `Notification` (`kind: "info"`, `status: "unread"`) that broadcasts in real-time via `Notification#broadcast!`

No `send_message` call, no canvas component tools (`add_canvas_component`, etc.) are used. The output channel is: **DB page + notification broadcast**.

The notification text is hardcoded as: `"Your morning briefing is ready"` / `"Weather and top stories for today."`.

---

### 7. Self-Scheduling (`reschedule_for_tomorrow`)

At the end of every run the skill inserts a new `ScheduledTask` row:

```ruby
hour = (Ai::Config.get("briefing_hour") || "7").to_i
tomorrow = Time.now + 86400
scheduled_time = Time.new(tomorrow.year, tomorrow.month, tomorrow.day, hour, 0, 0)

Ai::ScheduledTask.create!(
  title: "Daily Briefing",
  description: "Run the daily briefing skill",
  scheduled_for: scheduled_time,
  skill_name: "daily_briefing",
  parameters: {}
)
```

The default is **7:00 AM** the next day. The hour is configurable via `Config.get("briefing_hour")`.

---

### 8. Complete Data Flow Summary

```
Rufus every 60s
  -> ScheduledTask.due (scheduled_for <= now AND status=pending)
  -> ScheduledTaskRunnerJob.perform_later(task.id)
     -> SkillRecord.find_by(name: "daily_briefing")
     -> skill_record.load_and_execute  (loads skills/daily_briefing.rb, calls DailyBriefing.new.execute)
        -> fetch_weather  ->  wttr.in JSON API  (no key)
        -> fetch_news     ->  HN Firebase REST API (no key, 5 stories)
        -> build_briefing_html  (single HTML string, uses .card/.section-heading design classes)
        -> upsert_page    ->  AiPage slug="daily-briefing" created/updated in DB
        -> create_notification  ->  Notification.broadcast! -> SSE -> Turbo Stream -> browser
        -> reschedule_for_tomorrow  ->  new ScheduledTask row for 7 AM next day
```

---

### Key Observations

- Weather and HN **are bundled together** in a single skill run and a single page -- they are not separate skills.
- The city defaults to **Zurich** (matches Gregory's location from the memory file).
- The briefing hour is configurable via the `Config` model (`briefing_hour` key), defaulting to `7`.
- There is **no `workspace/skills/` directory** -- the skill file lives at `/home/greg/Developer/ai.rb/skills/daily_briefing.rb` (repo root `skills/` folder), not inside `workspace/`.
- The base class `Ai::Skill` is referenced but not found as a standalone file -- it may be defined inline elsewhere or expected to be created.

# frozen_string_literal: true require 'net/http' require 'json' class DailyBriefing < Ai::Skill description "Fetches weather and news, creates a daily briefing page" param :city, :string, required: false, description: "City for weather (default: Zurich)" def call(city: nil) city ||= Ai::Config.get("briefing_city") || "Zurich" weather = fetch_weather(city) news = fetch_news html = build_briefing_html(city, weather, news) page = upsert_page(html) create_notification(page) reschedule_for_tomorrow { success: true, page_url: "/pages/#{page.slug}" } end private def fetch_weather(city) uri = URI("https://wttr.in/#{URI.encode_www_form_component(city)}?format=j1") response = Net::HTTP.get(uri) data = JSON.parse(response) current = data["current_condition"]&.first || {} { temp_c: current["temp_C"], feels_like_c: current["FeelsLikeC"], humidity: current["humidity"], description: current.dig("weatherDesc", 0, "value"), wind_kmph: current["windspeedKmph"], wind_dir: current["winddir16Point"] } rescue => e Ai.logger.error "Weather fetch failed: #{e.message}" { error: e.message } end def fetch_news uri = URI("https://hacker-news.firebaseio.com/v0/topstories.json") response = Net::HTTP.get(uri) story_ids = JSON.parse(response).first(5) story_ids.map do |id| story_uri = URI("https://hacker-news.firebaseio.com/v0/item/#{id}.json") story_data = JSON.parse(Net::HTTP.get(story_uri)) { title: story_data["title"], url: story_data["url"], score: story_data["score"] } end rescue => e Ai.logger.error "News fetch failed: #{e.message}" [] end def build_briefing_html(city, weather, news) date = Time.now.strftime("%A, %B %-d, %Y") html = <<~HTML

#{date}

Weather in #{city}

HTML if weather[:error] html += "

Could not fetch weather: #{weather[:error]}

\n" else html += <<~HTML

#{weather[:temp_c]}°C

Feels like #{weather[:feels_like_c]}°C

#{weather[:description]}

Humidity: #{weather[:humidity]}%

Wind: #{weather[:wind_kmph]} km/h #{weather[:wind_dir]}

HTML end html += <<~HTML

Top Stories

HTML if news.empty? html += "

Could not fetch news.

\n" else html += "
    \n" news.each do |story| link = story[:url] ? "#{story[:title]}" : story[:title] html += "
  • #{link} (#{story[:score]} pts)

# Self-Contained Widget Package System ## Context Canvas widgets are currently just raw HTML blobs — no type dispatch, no widget-specific JS, no separation from core canvas code. The weather widget is hardcoded HTML with no live data. Creating a new widget type means scattering logic across canvas_controller.js, inline HTML strings in tools, and duplicated rendering in 3+ places. **Goal:** Each widget = one Ruby file (+ optional JS file). Auto-discovered, auto-rendered, auto-refreshable. The AI can create unlimited widget types by adding files — never touching core canvas/chat code. ## Architecture ``` ai/widgets/ base_widget.rb # Base class: registry, render_component_html, refresh DSL note_widget.rb # Static card (existing "Add Note") clock_widget.rb # Client-side JS (ticking clock) weather_widget.rb # Server-side refresh (live weather data) web/public/js/widgets/ registry.js # window.widgetBehaviors = {}; window.registerWidget(type, {init, destroy}) clock.js # Clock tick interval ``` **Convention:** `component_type` in DB maps to `widget_type` in Ruby and `data-widget-type` in DOM. Metadata JSON drives rendering — `content` is a rendered HTML cache. ## Files to Modify | File | Change | |---|---| | `ai/widgets/base_widget.rb` | **New** — base class with ObjectSpace registry, `render_component_html`, `render_content`, `refresh_data!` | | `ai/widgets/note_widget.rb` | **New** — simple card widget | | `ai/widgets/clock_widget.rb` | **New** — clock with timezone metadata | | `ai/widgets/weather_widget.rb` | **New** — weather with refresh, renders from metadata | | `web/public/js/widgets/registry.js` | **New** — `registerWidget(type, {init, destroy})` | | `web/public/js/widgets/clock.js` | **New** — `setInterval` tick | | `ai/models/canvas_component.rb` | Add `render_html` and `render_content` delegating to widget registry | | `ai/bootstrap.rb` | Add `Dir[root.join('ai/widgets/**/*.rb')]` load line | | `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Replace inline HTML with `component.render_html` | | `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` | Same | | `web/app.rb` | Same in POST route; add `GET /api/widget_types` endpoint; add auto-render after create | | `web/public/js/controllers/canvas_controller.js` | Extend `initComponent` with widget dispatch; add `destroyComponent`; fetch widget types for dynamic context menu | | `web/public/js/controllers/chat_footer_controller.js` | Add `data-widget-type`/`data-widget-metadata` to `_renderCanvasComponent` | | `web/public/js/application.js` | Import `registry.js` and `clock.js` | ## Implementation ### Step 1: Base Widget Class Create `ai/widgets/base_widget.rb`: ```ruby module Ai module Widgets class BaseWidget class << self attr_reader :widget_type_name, :menu_label_text, :menu_icon_text def widget_type(name) = @widget_type_name = name.to_s def menu_label(label) = @menu_label_text = label def menu_icon(icon) = @menu_icon_text = icon def refreshable? = false def refresh_interval = nil def default_metadata = {} def registry @registry ||= ObjectSpace.each_object(Class) .select { |c| c < BaseWidget && c.widget_type_name } .each_with_object({}) { |c, h| h[c.widget_type_name] = c } end def reset_registry! = @registry = nil def for_type(type) = registry[type.to_s] end def initialize(component) @component = component @metadata = component.metadata || {} end def render_content = @component.content || '' def render_component_html c = @component style = "left:#{c.x}px;top:#{c.y}px;width:#{c.width}px;" style += "height:#{c.height}px;" if c.height meta_json = (@metadata || {}).to_json.gsub('"', '"') <<~HTML
#{render_content}
HTML end def refresh_data! = false end end end ``` ### Step 2: Three Example Widgets **`ai/widgets/note_widget.rb`** — static card: ```ruby widget_type 'card' menu_label 'Add Note' menu_icon '📝' def render_content @metadata['text'] || @component.content || '

Double-click to edit...

' end ``` **`ai/widgets/clock_widget.rb`** — client-side JS: ```ruby widget_type 'clock' menu_label 'Add Clock' menu_icon '🕐' def self.default_metadata = { timezone: 'UTC', label: 'UTC' } def render_content # Renders static shell; JS widget behavior animates the display end ``` **`ai/widgets/weather_widget.rb`** — server-side refresh: ```ruby widget_type 'weather' menu_label 'Add Weather' menu_icon '☀️' def self.refreshable? = true def self.refresh_interval = 1800 def render_content # Renders from @metadata keys: city, temp, description, etc. end def refresh_data! # Fetch from weather API, update metadata + content, return true if changed end ``` ### Step 3: CanvasComponent Model — Render Delegation Add to `ai/models/canvas_component.rb`: ```ruby def render_html widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) widget_class ? widget_class.new(self).render_component_html : fallback_html end def render_content_html widget_class = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.for_type(component_type) widget_class ? widget_class.new(self).render_content : content end private def fallback_html # Same inline HTML as today (backward compat for unknown types) end ``` ### Step 4: DRY Up Broadcast HTML (3 sites → `component.render_html`) - `ai/tools/add_canvas_component_tool.rb` — replace `component_html(c)` method body with `component.render_html` - `ai/tools/update_canvas_component_tool.rb` — same - `web/app.rb` POST `/api/pages/:id/components` — replace inline HTML with `component.render_html` Also: after component creation, auto-render content from widget if content is blank: ```ruby # In POST route / add_canvas_component_tool, after create!: if component.content.blank? rendered = component.render_content_html component.update_column(:content, rendered) if rendered != component.content end ``` ### Step 5: Bootstrap Loading Add to `ai/bootstrap.rb` after jobs loading: ```ruby Dir[root.join('ai/widgets/**/*.rb')].sort.each { |f| require f } ``` ### Step 6: Widget Types API Endpoint Add to `web/app.rb` inside `r.on 'api'`: ```ruby r.on 'widget_types' do r.get do types = Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.registry.map do |type, klass| { type: type, label: klass.menu_label_text || type.titleize, icon: klass.menu_icon_text, defaults: klass.default_metadata } end { widget_types: types } end end ``` ### Step 7: JS Widget Registry + Clock **`web/public/js/widgets/registry.js`:** ```js window.widgetBehaviors = {} window.registerWidget = (type, behavior) => { window.widgetBehaviors[type] = behavior } ``` **`web/public/js/widgets/clock.js`:** ```js registerWidget('clock', { init(el, metadata) { const tz = metadata.timezone || 'UTC' const display = el.querySelector('[data-clock-display]') const tick = () => { display.textContent = new Date().toLocaleTimeString('en-US', { timeZone: tz, hour12: false }) } tick(); el._clockInterval = setInterval(tick, 1000) }, destroy(el) { clearInterval(el._clockInterval) } }) ``` **`application.js`** — add imports before controllers: ```js import "/js/widgets/registry.js" import "/js/widgets/clock.js" ``` ### Step 8: Canvas Controller — Widget Lifecycle + Dynamic Menu In `canvas_controller.js`: **`initComponent`** — add widget dispatch: ```js initComponent(el) { el.style.zIndex = el.dataset.z || 0 const type = el.dataset.widgetType if (type && window.widgetBehaviors?.[type]?.init) { const meta = JSON.parse(el.dataset.widgetMetadata || '{}') window.widgetBehaviors[type].init(el, meta) } } ``` **Add `destroyComponent`** — called before removing nodes: ```js destroyComponent(el) { const type = el.dataset.widgetType if (type && window.widgetBehaviors?.[type]?.destroy) { window.widgetBehaviors[type].destroy(el) } } ``` **Dynamic context menu** — on connect, fetch `/api/widget_types` and build `canvasMenuItems` from the response instead of hardcoding. Fallback to hardcoded items if fetch fails. **Remove** hardcoded `addWeatherWidget` / `weatherWidgetHtml` methods — replaced by the generic `addWidget(type, x, y)` that POSTs with `component_type` and `metadata: defaultMetadata`. ### Step 9: chat_footer_controller.js — Metadata in Rendered HTML Update `_renderCanvasComponent(comp)` to include `data-widget-type` and `data-widget-metadata` attributes so widget init fires when components are loaded from the canvas API. ## Verification 1. `./ai.rb server` — starts clean, widgets auto-discovered 2. Right-click canvas — menu shows "Add Note", "Add Clock", "Add Weather" (from `/api/widget_types`) 3. Add a clock widget — ticks every second via JS 4. Add a note — double-click to edit still works 5. Add a weather widget — renders from metadata 6. Turbo Stream broadcast — add component on one tab, appears on another via SSE 7. Agent uses `add_canvas_component(component_type: 'clock', metadata: {timezone: 'Europe/Zurich', label: 'Zurich'})` — clock appears and ticks 8. Create a brand-new widget by adding one Ruby file — it shows up in context menu on next server restart

### Step 10: Widget Refresh Job

Create `ai/jobs/widget_refresh_job.rb` — a single job that refreshes all refreshable widgets:

```ruby
def perform
  Ai::Widgets::BaseWidget.registry.each do |type, widget_class|
    next unless widget_class.refreshable? && widget_class.refresh_interval
    CanvasComponent.where(component_type: type).find_each do |component|
      widget = widget_class.new(component)
      if widget.refresh_data!
        turbo = "<turbo-stream action=\"replace\" target=\"canvas-component-#{component.id}\">
                   <template>#{widget.render_component_html}</template></turbo-stream>"
        Ai::Web::TurboBroadcast.broadcast("canvas:#{component.ai_page_id}", turbo)
      end
    end
  end
end
```
